content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												For anyone that enjoys a challenging learning curve, building stuff that works and is interested in spaceflight this game is a must have.I have played this game a lot, and I can only reccomend it. There is a staggering amount of things to do, and more ways to go about accomplishing these things than can be listed.One thing that really strikes me is that there is always room for improvement. Sure you can build a humungus rocket to go to the moon, but maybe you are like me and like a challenge, so instead you take the time to perfect the rocket and get there and back with barely any margin.With KSP Squad has managed to make a remarkable game, one of a kind, and one that will be played for a long time. They continously keep updating the game with new content, tweaks etc., the community is great and the modding community in particular is stunning. Some of the Devs even have their own mods, pet projects etc. and the general quality standard for mods is incredibly high.KSP's aerodynamics are too simple? There is a mod for that!Bigger rocktes?  There is a mod for that!SciFi looking parts?  There is a mod for that!In depth colonization and resource system? Non-OP Space age technology (fusion, plasma etc)? Real scale everything? Realism? Beautification?  There is a mod each and every one of these and far, far more! And CKAN makes it ridiculously easy to install them all.TLDR; BUY THIS GAME

number of helpful: 9 of 10 people (90%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 3, 2014
Early Access Review
								I'm one of those people who never bought a game, relying on piracy for almost 15 years. KSP changed that.During more than one year of playing it and perhaps even 2000 hours of game time collected, I've never regret the spent money.As this is a work in progress, it can't be fully evaluated, but judging by the current status, it has crossed the line of just having a potential to become big. It really became big.Its Unity engine doesn't allow it to be very flexible for the developers because the bottleneck is Unity itself. Nevertheless, the game graphics is visually appealing.This is one of the most stable WIP games ever. Crashes are very rare even if one tweaks the game using various plugins and mods.It's educational, it's open to expanding by others and the community is fantastic. One of the most peaceful communities I've encountered online, probably due to the fact that such games aren't generally appealing to aggressive types of people.There is still much work to be done, but I already see this as one of the games that will become important in the history of computer games.

content:
Posted: January 23, 2015
Early Access Review
								A must have for space/rocket fans!KSP provides a large set of components and functionality with a relatively bug-free simulation of physics. I've read reviews mentioning repetitive crashes or the lack of Steam Workshop integration, I personally had 2 KSP crashes in all my game time (77 hours) so that is fairly alright. The mod installation is as simple as putting the mod folder into your GameData folder, that's it.Talking about mods, the mod support seems to be great. I've never looked into modding it myself, but since there are mods adding mineable ressources to planetoids or doing complete mapping scans from certain orbits there is a lot of room there :)Who do I recommend this to?"Engineers": People that like to Trial&Error in games, that like taking challenges and eventually mastering them. In KSP, the difficulty of these challenges depends on you (i.e. sending two rockets with station segments into orbit or try it in one turn, which is more cost efficient etc etc)"Organizers": People that love doing stuff as calculating orbits (orbital period, "best suitable inclination" and so on), Thrust-To-Mass Ratios and all the tons of numbers you find in rocket science :P"Pilots": People that have fun with coordinating a vessel in space near a fragile station to it's docking port ;)Most of you will be all three of them, but interestingly you can lay your focus on whichever you want.Also the humor of the game is amazing, so from my side:A BIG YES to Kerbal Space Program!(PS: If you decide to buy it now, check out Scott Manley's KSP tutorials. He's kind of the iconic figure of KSP tutorials and it will make your first hours a LOT more understandable)

number of helpful: 9 of 11 people (82%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 18, 2015
Early Access Review
								I'm a space enthusiast. I saw a video about KSP which depicted it as a silly and unrealistic game that made fun of serious efforts to explore space. Thankfully, my curiosity got the better of me and I decided to give the game a go. I'm glad I did.This is a game where I can design, build and fly spacecraft designed any way I like. The game is set in a fictional solar system filled with analogues of planets and moons of our own solar system. I can recreate past and present missions, learning how to land on KSP's Moon analogue, or construct and dock with a space station of my own design. I can also act out proposed future missions by visiting KSP's Mars analogue or other planetary body analogues.The game is not yet fully mature. We do not yet have realistic re-entry heating. We are not yet able to establish bases to utilise in-situ resources. These features are in development and will be implemented in due course. The next feature we are eagerly awaiting is an overhaul of aerodynamics and implementation of payload fairings and cargo bays.KSP is realistic without being inaccessible. I'm currently on 1434 hours played without installing any mods.

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 5, 2016
												People always talk about making games that are both fun and educational, lets be honest, most fail for one reason or another, not Kerbal! Kerbal space program, Coming in I didn't even understand how much I didn't know about orbital mechanics! But Kerbal space program unravels these secrets in a paced and comprehensive order and most importantly, its fun while doing it. Everything from the designing the rocket to performing the actual mission, you don't get near space the first few tries but you feel yourself improving every time, and every stage feels awe inspiring. My first Apollo style moon landing was a highlight to my summer for the sense of acomplishment it entailed. Even faliure can be fun, run out of fuel to early? mess up your design and realize after you make it to Duna?(mars), figure out what parts of the mission are salvageable, what science can still be performed. My first mission to Duna ran out of fuel before making into orbit but I was able to use the rotation control rockets to alter my path just enough to fling around its moon and slam into Dunas thin atmosphere to slow myself down. It's that kind of clever problem solving that brings the most satisfaction sometimes.

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: October 16, 2013
Early Access Review
								The more I play this game, the more I love it. Really, not enough good things can be said about this game. On the surface, it's cute and funny. Go a little deeper and you will find a surprisingly complex and intelligent space simulator, where you will learn something new every time you play it. Honestly, I'd pay twice the price for this much fun. $22.99 is a steal, and 300 hours in, I'm looking at 7 cents per hour for a hell of a good time. The mod community is also very vibrant and adds literally anything you can imagine: new paint jobs, altered physics, communication, fusion-powered engines, warp drives, hyperspace, and even asteroids. Seriously, give this game a shot. You won't regret it.

number of helpful: 6 of 6 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 21, 2016
												This game is very unique and extremely fun. It is very challenging, but also extremely satisfying when you accomplish something. In addition, it quite expands your knowledge about physics.There is no other game like this, but in some ways it bears similarities to Dwarf Fortress - both games have sharp learning curve, are extremely difficult beyond the very basics (albeit KSP is pretty forgiving) and the lesson you learn from them is that losing is fun. KSP simulates physics very well, it includes objects burning when reentering atmosphere, different gravity on various bodies, and the whole solar system is actually simulated (planets and asteroids orbiting Sun, moons orbiting planets), while the game is a sandbox allowing you to do whatever you want. Do you want to fly to the Moon? Sure. Do you want to do research on an asteroid? Sure. Do you want to take that asteroid down  to Earth? Sure! (But it's not gonna be easy!)Oh, and you do actually learn some physics in the game. You have to. This, however, lets you understand space exploration and why is it so difficult and takes so much time. After all, in KSP you get to do a lot of stuff yourself!The game doesn't have any drawbacks either. Perhaps some rare bugs or crashes, but very few. Other than that, the game is flawless.It's not just the best space game. It's actually one of the best games ever made. I recommend it to literally everyone. Download a demo to try it out first and fly to the Moon.

content:
Posted: August 8, 2015
												I came to this came on the wave of Reddit hype a few years ago since then, I have: put it down, deleted, reintalled, flung mice around my room, printed off screenshots and actually shouted in triumph upon landing on the Mun.The worth of a game, a film, of art in general comes down to the emotional response it elicits. KSP has caused me actual ♥♥♥♥ing trauma, total euphoria, crushing despondancy, childlike wonder, intellectual overreach and many other feelings beyond mere words.Building a rocket, blowing up said rocket on the launch pad, fixing the staging, running out of fuel before circularising, consulting our Lord Scott Manley, circularising, achieving orbit and just staring out the window at tiny Kerbin before burning retrograde and coming back home. To recommend this game, is to recommend the spectrum of life's emotions.

number of helpful: 7 of 8 people (88%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 16, 2014
Early Access Review
If you are interested in space travel, and astrophysics, try this game!You might learn something. Or, if you are already an expert, you can see with your own eyes how these things really work. Of course, not everything is modelled perfectly, for example, you don't have to worry about the heat during re-entry, the aerodynamic drag works in a kind of a gamey way, and I can guarantee you that some of your earliest designs are gonna resemble a soft, shaking sausage instead of a rocket, but at the end of the day, you are gonna feel like you just built a real rocket.If you are interested in original, deep, addictive, sometimes awe-inspiring games, TRY THIS GAME!!When your build your first orbit-capable rocket.Your first spacewalk.When you first reach Mün.Your first modular space-station.When you first flip and crash your rover on the surface of another planet.When you learn about the fantastic stuff OTHER PEOPLE can build in this game.Just some of the great moments you'll experience in KSP.The game might look complicated, and yes, you CAN build some pretty complicated stuff, but the learning curve is surprisingly easy, of course watching some youtube videos help a lot. Graphically, it's one of the most beautiful games I've ever seen. Yes, the textures are not really detailed, the models aren't, either, but when you first align your rocket against the Sun so you can only see a silhouette, with your pilot next to it on an EVA, when you drive your Rover through Mün's canyon, or when you turn the lights on on your shiny new space station are as screenshot-worthy moments as anything ever.The building possibilites are endless, especially with the great mods out there. Of course, so are the possibilities to explode right at the launch pad. ;)Seriously, try this game, playing KSP is one of the most special experiences any game can give.EDIT: Oh, and don't be bothered by the fact that it's still Early Access, the game is constantly evolving, and felt like a finished game even months ago.

number of helpful: 8 of 10 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 16, 2014
Early Access Review
								My most rewarding gaming experience ever comes from rescuing one of my kerbals, trapped on the Mun after a routine science mission had a rough landing, damaging the parachutes of the vessel and rendering it incapable of returning to Kerbin. The rescue mission had to be quick as the life support (TAC life support mod) was running out for Jebadiah Kerman. After rendevousing with the damaged ship in a low Munar orbit, the rescue vessel set about returning to Kerbin with much less fuel than planned. It was tooth and nails as the vessel only just managed to deorbit itself, skimming through Kerbin's atmosphere multiple times before finally landing, all astronauts safe.That is the thing about Kerbal Space Program, everyone has a story about the game which they want to tell. You design your own missions- they go well, success! they go wrong, rescue mission! You design ships and redesign them. You plan your missions, and you fly those missions.The game is still being developed and new features are gradually getting rolled out. And if you ever want more, the awesome modding community has you covered, adding♥♥♥♥♥♥loads of more content and gameplay, from extra parts to requiring life support for kerbals or even a connection link for unmanned vessels.P.S. I recommend checking out Scott Manley's youtube videos for tutorials and to just see someone who does awesome things in the game.

content:
Posted: May 10, 2016
												My favorite game. There's so much to do, and so many places to go. A whole  world  solar system of freedom and opportunity awaits!You can play in sandbox, science mode, or career mode. In sandbox mode, you have unlimited funds, and everything is unlocked. In science mode, you have infinite funds, but you need to unlock things with science. In career mode, you have limited funds and science, as well as reputation. You must accept contracts from companies to fund your space program, and progress through the tech tree.The game has in-depth tutorials and a guide, as well as different scenarios to try out. The community around the game is great, and Squad (the company that makes KSP) is great. I have seen them implement many things the community asks for, and even bring modders on to the team to help.Speaking of mods, there exists a plethora to choose from. Whether you want to make your game easier, harder, better looking, more realistic, or crazy, there is a mod for you. They include things from graphics overhauls to aerodynamic overhauls to vast quantities of new parts to autopilot systems you code yourself.The game is both simple and challenging at the same time. It's easy enough to build a rocket, but can you make it fly? Can you get into orbit? How about to the  Moon  Mun? What about  Mars  Duna? The answers may be no at first, but you learn. You slowly understad more and more, and after playing the game for a while, the answer becomes yes. And in that moment, you realize: "Hey! I know how space works! This is orbital mechanics! And I know how to do it!" It gives you a wondrous feeling of accomplishment, each time you do something new. That feeling barely fades, as I still feel my heart swell a little every time I land on the Mun.So go ahead, give the game a shot. It may seem daunting, but it's really quite fun -- and deceptively simple.How hard can rocket science be anyway?

number of helpful: 8 of 10 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 5, 2013
Early Access Review
								Kerbal Space Program basically sums up the entire reason as to why I wish I were an astronaut/rocket scientist, and the entire reason as to why there is no way in hell I could ever be one.The game has two modes (as of the time of this writing), Career, and Sandbox.  Sandbox is exactly what it sounds like, minus the cat poop and the lost action figures (never forget you little Anakin!).  In sandbox, you build a rocket ship or a space plane, and you go to space.  Half of the time...  The other half is spent trying to figure out why in the hell did that stage not properly go off, only to realize you didn't actually attach your rockets to that stage...  But anyways, sandbox mode is the mode you play when you want to make a giant ship in a few minutes and fly it into the sun.  Because why?  Because Science!The second mode, Career, is basically "Here's a couple of pieces, those guys over there are the pilots, see if we can't get this into space."  The beginning parts are spent mindlessly launching rockets into the ground because you have no idea what you are doing, and when you finally figure out what you're doing, you can have some fun.  In Career, you gain science points for everything you do.  Like, everything...  Such as EVAing a Kerbal while you're still launching, dropping a mysterious goo on the ground, into the water, into space, into orbit, and pretty much anywhere you can drop that goo, you'll get science for it.  You can get science for successful missions, unsuccessful missions, missions that you didn't think could go wrong but did, missions you thought would never be possible but was because who needs logic.This is definitely one of my new favorite games out there.  Although, as much as I'd hate to admit it, this game is MUCH better being played on a controller (or joystick, which is awesome if you can), just because the little fine tuning you have to do can be a pain when using your keyboard.The only complaint I have is that I freaking got Jeb stuck into orbit with no jetpack fuel in Career mode, and he isn't even in the ship anymore, and so the only way I could save him is by very, VERY precise calculations, that I'm too lazy to do and end up just winging it.  I mean, I could just terminate him and he'll respawn eventually, but it's FREAKING JEB!  I CAN'T KILL JEB!So anyways, I hope you found this review helpful, and I would ABSOLUTELY recommend this game to people.  But, I suggest packing enough fuel to get out of orbit, or wait until you have docking ports...  Then you won't end up with Jeb stuck in space...

content:
Posted: May 2, 2015
												Still charming, now with extra awesomeness.Construction UI's gotten even more solid and impressive. Flight model and air resistance and heat management are now unremarkably good (that's a good thing).  Many flight controls are still difficult to discover, but the worst of the old flaws are gone (it no longer trains you to rely on the space bar being "do the next thing" only to later on make that an insta-lose-but-only-sometimes button). While you're in-game it still won't show you the keyboard shortcuts and you kinda still have to find out about the quicksave key (F5 save, hold-F9 load) yourself before you can go check the keys midflight.  You can't always quicksave.Caveats as of 1.0.2: This game will enthrall you so thoroughly that _hours_ will pass by.  If you don't  quicksave regularly then sooner or later (leaning towards "sooner") you'll lose an entire evening's meticulous and irreproducible work.  * Quicksave isn't really for exploring different flight plans, it's for defense against the UI and to a lesser extent some minor bugs. Don't use the hard-mode option that shuts off quicksaves. * Go into the settings input options and shut off the staging function in any but staging mode.  The default setting makes the space bar a pun (but only sometimes): toggle RCS between linear and rotation mode, oh, and also jettison your last engine.  The controls shouldn't be more counterintuitive than orbital mechanics. They really shouldn't. * If you hit the can't-place-a-maneuver-node UI bug, try deleting other maneuvers, farthest away first. That sometimes fixes it for me.Ragdoll Berts and a space program.  Charming, genius, progress requires ambition (it's a sandbox, after all), very demanding but always with clear reason game.  I think this is going to remain my builder of choice for a long time.

content:
Posted: October 14, 2016
												This is the story of Jeb KerminJeb wanted his entire life to become an astronaut. He'd look into the stars each night and think, "One day." With the arrival of the new Kerbal Space Program, Jeb didn't hesitate. He was the only willing pilot in the lot that offered to join. Jeb traversed dangerous missions of small hunks of metal launched at high velocities. Jeb endured it all, explosions, heat reaching the thousands of degree. Jeb endured.One day, Jeb was offered a special mission. "We're gonna get you into orbit." said the commander.Jeb crawled into the rocket, the rocket of Icarus. Strapping himself into the pod, he prepared the final checks before launching once more into Kermin's sky. As he exited the atmosphere and entered into space, as he had before, Jeb couldn't help but feel worry. Something was not right. Looking at his live orbit map revealed a terrifying sight. Rather than circle Kermin, Jeb was destined to sail straight on...into space. Jeb's heart sank as the engines stopped. He had no fuel.Time passed. Days. Months. Maybe a year. Jeb didn't know. His orbit map revealed finally a circle.A circle around the sun. Jeb had entered space at such a velocity, he missed Kermin's orbit, and rather caught the sun.He was to sail past three different planets, including Kermin, to orbit the sun.Jeb felt no pain. He felt no sadness. Jeb looked on at the flaming ball of gas that was his new home. He smiled, for Jeb had the life he always wanted. To traverse the stars, see the planets.Icarus had succeeded. History repeated.Jeb was with the stars.UPDATE: Years have passed. All electricity in the pod have drained. For seemingly forever, Jeb floated high above the sun in a never ending circle. Tiring of the pod, Jeb prepared to make his mark on history.Jeb strapped on his suit and ejected from the pod. He took a deep breath as he closed his eyes, letting go of the ladder holding him from safety. He drifted away, unsure of his destination. Unable to control himself, Jeb closed his eyes as he soared through the stars, drifting both higher and lower than the mysterious Eeloo, on the farthest reaches of the system.A frozen tear drifted down Jeb's eye as he floated away, never once again seeing another planet. No Kerbin. No Mun. Only the Sun.Jeb was unsure of what would happen. Jeb didn't mind. He would endure. He would survive.Or Icarus would win.TL;DR i messed up trying to orbit kerbin and managed to orbit the sun on accident and jeb's flying all across the entire system. today i told him to abandon his pod and just drift away in space.god bless you jebediah kermin.Pics for anyone interested or don't believe meOrbit map: http://images.akamai.steamusercontent.com/ugc/248087970818710036/55ECF3E4067555F056FA6E63A254F1B0840E5CBA/Jeb orbiting the sun: http://images.akamai.steamusercontent.com/ugc/248087970821367339/E47FE9B0564285E7F6DE6A599887F237ED1CFE5B/

content:
Posted: December 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								Whilst still technically in Alpha, I don't think a game has had me coming back to it with every patch this often since Minecraft! Beta release is just around the corner but I do hope they continue to add more things. That's not to say there isn't a lot there already... but the potential is huge!Regarding the game itself... build it, fly it, crash it. Build it again, fly it again, crash it again. Things will go wrong, adjustments will need to be made, and kerbals will get lost in space. It's ok though because that means you can try to rescue them! When that fails, try to rescue both ships at the same time with a bigger ship! In no time you'll have space debris surrounding your home planet, but in the process you'll learn orbital mechanics, docking proceedures and the best landing techniques for the dozens of planets in the system at present. Then there are asteroids too! Give this game a shot, if you don't want to pay out right away I believe there's a demo available from the main website.

number of helpful: 5 of 5 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 15, 2014
Early Access Review
								If you like space, science and space science you'll love this magical little gem of a game. It's *not* easy, which I happen to like. I'm sick of games that I can beat in a matter of hours. Kerbal Space Program is hard - hard as♥♥♥♥♥♥in some cases - and as such it can be incredibly rewarding to land on a new planet, moon, or just build a cool new thing. There are some fairly significant downsides: 1. The tutorials are terrible. Maybe I'm just stupid? I ended up having to figure most of the game out myself and spent tons of time looking things up on YouTube and the game's Wiki. 2. It's a *little* slow to start. Because the controls are a bit obscure at first I wasn't sure I was going to like it. I ended up playing it immediately after buying it, becoming frustrated and shelving it for about two weeks. But I am *SO* glad I gave it a second chance. 3. There're still some weird bugs, but the KSP team seems quite active in working them out. It's still only just now in beta so bugs are to be expected. Unfortunately the worst one I've encountered managed to corrupt my best saves, forcing me to start over after having a nearly completed tech tree.However I haven't had this problem again in over a month now - maybe it was fixed, maybe I'm just lucky.Anyway, despite these problems, the game is ABSOLUTELY worth every penny and I'm incredibly excited for future content and witnessing the continuing development of this game. Obviously as a video game it's not quite the same thing as actually being an astronaut, an engineer or ground control, but it does give you an entirely new appreciation for what NASA, the ESA, Roscosmos, and any other space agency do every day. It *is* rocket science! Just a touch dumbed down for those of us without Ph.Ds :DBuild all the things.Buy all the Kerbal Space Programs.

content:
Posted: April 3, 2013
Early Access Review
								This game is very hard to describe as it is one of a kind.I could label it as a space program simulator but that really doesn't do Kerbal Space Program justice.Kerbal Space Program is essentially a game about managing your own space program, building your own rockets, planes, ships, space stations, landers, or any silly contraption you imagine really, and taking your poor victims.. err Kerbals.. to the stars! It runs on a semi-realistic physics and astronomy system where you can see every single part of your ship explode spectacularly as your poor Kerbals show their expressions of despair throughout the ride.This is a game about building and exploring the Kerbal Solar System and each of it's astral bodies, about making silly contraptions and planting flags on unexplored worlds.And if you ever want to go beyond the far reaches of the solar system, there's also a plethora of mods already available for Kerbal Space Program despite it being only in alpha stage... Even a multiplayer mod.I haven't sinked as many hours into a single videogame for a very long time as I did with Kerbal Space Program.This is Rocket Science the videogame and is an ABSOLUTE MUST!WARNING SIDE-EFFECTS:You will learn a few concepts of aerodynamics, physics and astronomy just by having fun!

Early Access Review
								Kerbal Space Program (KSP) is really awesome, if you are into space exploration the non-fictional way.Your imagination is not limited.You can practically send anything into space or on other celestial bodies.This is, if it is able to leave the surface of your home planet without exploding... ;-)Most people like to play the game just for fun, sending rockets and crews up into orbit or to the Mun (the moon of the planet Kerbin, where your Space Center is located).You can gather science there to either way collect data or enhance your research of new technologies and rocket-/plane-parts, if you play career-mode (rather then sandbox mdoe, where you already habe all parts) or you can just do it FTW!Be warned the learning curve is pretty steep, which means you will have some hard lessons to learn, until you really pull of your first spaceflight.Nontheless this should not hinder you in downloading the DEMO first and try out if you have the guts to send "Kerbal"s into space or not. ;-)Kerbals are the little eggheads doing funny facial expressions to the right lower screen.The most famous is Jebediah Kerbin (aka Jeb).He will be your first voluntary (test-)pilot.This game is for all ages and space enthusiast, who see more in the sky, then shining lights in the nightsky... ;-)

content:
Posted: December 6, 2016
												KSP is wonderful, unique, difficult, confusing, elating and all manner of other things bundled up into a deep and long-lasting package. The core of the game is all about building space-rockets, and flying them to the furthest reaches of the Kerbal solar system. Sounds fun eh! Just be aware that this is not some arcade-game were you can just shoot oversized fire-crackers into space. KSP is a full-blown space-program simulation.The upshot of this is that building rockets that really work is hard. If you want to succeed at KSP, you're going to have to spend a lot of time and effort getting to grips with how the simulation works, and in the process you're going to have to learn at least the very basic aspects of physics and even rocket-science that underpin this game.Sound daunting? It is, and in many ways that is the beauty of this game. At first you'll fail and fail hard. You'll build rockets that have no business being in the air, let alone venturing into space. You'll loose Kerbins to the deep void as you run out of fuel or otherwise mess up.But, spend some time reading the community guides, watching some YouTube vidoes on the principles of flight and you'll start to get the hang of things. You'll manage to launch a rocket into stable orbit and return it to Kerbin. Next you'll find yourself landing on one of the two moons that orbit Kerbin. And then from there, the challenges grow.The one down-side to this game is that it really does not contain the information needed to teach you how to play it. You cannot just 'wing it' when it comes to building rockets. In order to get past the most crude stages possible, you're either going to have to already be well trained in physics at degree level, or you're going to have to venture outside of the game and find the information you need to calculate the all important variables you're going to need to build successful rockets.Do I recommend this game? Yes, provided you're up for spending some serious time and effort getting to grips with it. There is nothing else quite like it, and you can learn a lot of interesting real-world physics while learning to play this. It's not, however, a game that will appeal to those looking for more instant fun.

number of helpful: 6 of 7 people (86%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 8, 2015
												Kerbal has a steep learning curve, but once you've figured out the mechanics, the reward of plotting out & achieving a goal is one the best experiences I've had in gaming in years!In the space of 40 hours, I started off barely managing to launch a rocket several thousand feet into the air. Now I'm fully capable of being able to both create a space faring craft & plot a course to recover a stranded astronaut circling around the orbit of the Mun (Kerbal's moon) over several million miles away.This isn't even scratching the surface of future possibilities I could attempt. I could perform a moon landing. Lift & place a space station into a stable orbit or travel to several of the other planetary bodies in the solar system.Much like an advanced 'Banjo Kazooie Nuts & Bolts' there's very little hand holding with a bare minimum of instruction of how to perform any of these outrageous feats. It takes the right combination of a well designed vessel, a correctly plotted route of orbital eclipses, skillful piloting & finally luck. Once you have all these, it's not long before you're complimenting yourself on a job well done & planning out what your next grand project is going to be.With charming & fluid presentation, extensive & encouraged mod support, atmospheric soundtrack & both career plus sandbox mode included. There's very little this game does wrong.You'll be doing yourself a disservice not giving this game a go!

number of helpful: 7 of 9 people (78%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 7, 2014
Early Access Review
								KSP might honestly be the best sandbox game I have ever played.  Everyone seems to make comments about this games steep learning curve, but the reality of it is, while you are struggling trying to figure out the controls and dynamics of this game, you are probably having a load of fun blowing rockets up and watching your little green men screaming in horror (except for Jebediah, who is always cheering).  Nothing about this games learning curve is a deterrent.  It admittedly took me a couple hours to get the hang of things myself.  But while I was learning, I was having a lot of fun just messing up stuff and laughing at how quickly (or slowly) my launch fell apart.  Now that I feel I have "mastered" space docking and world landings, I'm still finding tons of new things to do, explore and try to recreate.  Also, the physics in this game are spot on, all the way through.  Its amazing how much learning this game really seems like it can provide.  I highly recommend this to all.  KSP is addictive, fun, and hilarious.KSP is still in early access.  So there is a lot of new content still coming out, and the community for this game is great.  Some of the community mods I've used have really blown me away.  This game is only going to get more awesome moving forward.  Buy this game and thank me later.

content:
Posted: November 26, 2013
Early Access Review
								If you don't know anything about the space program or orbit maneuvers, this is a hilariously fun game of attempting to build rockets and often causing massive explosions while your cute little green pilots scream on in horror (except for Jebediah, who is cheering all the way). Laugh at your new build, where you've strapped on dozens of boosters, and be rolling on the floor during launch as you watch everything slowly (or, quickly) fall apart.If you know vaguely of the space program and think learning something about how to get things into space will be fun, this is a science kit in a box. Have all the fun above, plus you'll learn what "freefall" and "orbit" and "retrograde" really mean with hands-on experience. Relive the Apollo missions to the moon (or for Kerbals, the Mun), simulate real NASA missions (or try to and learn much as you stay up all night trying to make your rocket fly correctly). Addictive, cute, and fun.If you've mastered space docking and other-world-landing in other games, you'll still appreciate the excellent physics and the cute take on what is often a difficult genre to break into. The physics are all there and are quite good- you could teach a class using many of the features even in this early beta. With community mods, the physics get even better (or crazier, as you wish). Fans have even programmed automated burn correction programs so you can do a professional job. Calculate delta-vee and puzzle as your probe lands precisely where it was supposed to based on your mathematical calculations- in a game featuring cute bobble-headed green men.

								I have followed Kerbal Space Program for a long time and it has gone from a good game to epic! content:
Posted: May 18, 2015
												Before play KSP I have no ideas how hard it is, to design something that is able to go to the space and come back in one piece.Exploration is human's nature, our curiosity drive us into the deep space imagining what will be waiting for us. Well, lucky you, if you are a science nerd, rocket fetish, got a lot of A plus on you Physic's examinations, KSP is the perfect game for you to spend some time for a adventure. From my experience, KSP has no flaws, apparently my expertise aspects are limited to artistic titles, video games,game designs. For science, I'm not even an amateur but if you ask me if there are any features that I wish was in the game or will be added, I would like see more solar systems and most importantly flora and fauna.So far my suggestions seems intriguing, but there's a problem for gamer who wish to see faster results, if so,I warn you that you won't go further into the game. That will be a waste of money, in my opinion. KSP has some necessary built in tutorials but that won't be enough for someone like me, amateurs, to get into orbit. Don't worry, that doesn't mean we are just going to watch others building fancy things. There is a joke about KSP, whoever ask a question in KSP community thousands reply "Scott Manley"! Luckily we have our self a mentor on Youtube to teach us all the essentials that is required to "enjoy" the game. Assuming you are an amateur like me, whichever mode you started you will either get overwhelmed by all the parts that is displaying in front of you and you can't even make a damn thing out of them, or you are staring at a 4 or 5 parts and you have no ideas where this is going. If you are not a patience gamer, KSP can only be a cheap fun, you build some weird aircraft and spacecraft, fly around, click some buttons. Then KSP is definitely not a game for you and that's why spend times watching Scott Manley's tutorial is required.I had a hard time to learn the essentials, but Scott Manley is professional enough if you pay attention to his lessons. Most of the gamers will probably think, why the heck do you need to learn to play a game? Well KSP provide a strong realistic feelings (career mode), gravity, weight, budgets, design possibly everything that is related to build a spacecraft in real life is in this game. You can play it casually but you won't fully dig into this game. Failure will be inevitable, especially to people like me, I know very little things about spacecrafts, going through atmospheres, get overheated, can't even lift off the ground, can't return to ground, can't make a round orbit, suck at rescue mission, can't go to "moon". These frustrations are necessary but will eventually beat you, and you will rage quit. I remember I was doing a rescue mission where there are 3 astronauts need to be saved in low orbits, I successfully extract all of them but I got overheated and exploded when returning to "Earth". I spent merely 6 hours on that mission and yes, I didn't save it.Overall, KSP is a high quality space simulator, and a lot of potentials for you to discover, forgot to mention that KSP fully supporting mods which make this game even better! I do suggest you play the original game first then try some new mods. KSP gave me a lot of good memories, the moment that I reach the "moon", the moment that I reached north pole, you really feel that all that efforts worth it and it is so thrilling and satisfying to achieve something in KSP. That's what makes this game so special, after I became a decent player, I started to realize why conquering space is not that easy, as the title says. A true experience about learning and practicing space and aero technologies that you will feel. Highly recommended! TO SPACE!

Posted: November 13, 2015
												Even with the seemingly impossible challenges, and even harder choice of buying a game that might not seem worth it, I recommend it fully. There's so much for you to do on this game, with its realism, and the hundreds of parts it tosses at you when you open the VAB or Spaceplane Hanger. The planets, moons, and asteriods each have their own challenges and perks that differ from the rest. For example, Duna is farther from Kerbin than the Mun, but Duna has an atmosphere, which allows gliders and rocket planes to fly. The rocket parts and aerodynamics are nothing less than amazing, with engines that benifit and hinder you, fuel tanks that carry diffrent fuel sizes, muiltiple prepulsion methods and more. Not interested in rockets? Well, you got a full hanger with airplane parts choking the catalog. You can still aim for space, however, as it still supplies you with rocket parts, in whice you turn planes into SSTOs (single stage to orbit FYI), and vice versa. The exploration factor is nothing less than infinity. You got 7 planets, most of them with moons. They all have special chractheristics in which you either hate or love. Me myself,  having been  to EVERY planet and moon in this game, has not tired out yet. Why? Instead of just exploring, you can colonize and conquer. You got docking ports, which leads you to massive space stations. You can build bases on explored planets to supply fuel or power to passing ships. This game is truly amazing, even the slightest of space geeks will have fun in this. I recommend it fully 10/10

content:
Posted: April 30, 2013
Early Access Review
								There's nothing I can say about this game that hasn't already been raved about by thousands of other people...It's the most polished Early Access game you will ever see. KSP will spoil the very concept for you, because after playing it you'll think that Early Access is just a great way to get already-awesome games at a discount. No. Wrong. The vast majority of Early Access games are severely underdeveloped for even a partial release, and too  often misrepresent how far along they are on the path to completion. Some of them run out of funding or enthusiasm and never even reach completion, or declare "Mission Accomplished" and give you a game that falls far below the devs' original expectations and ignores the community's complaints. KSP makes "Early Access" into something of a joke, because it's more fun and more functional than anything that Electronic Arts or Creative Assembly have released in the last 10 years. Yeah, not even kidding when I say that.KSP has been a great game that just keeps getting better, and with the start of beta it just goes to another level entirely. Most folks would've been happy with the game as it was a year ago, but Squad is still picking up more and more momentum. They love their project, they're good at what they do, and they're incredibly responsive to the wishes of the KSP community, which is EXACTLY what Early Access is supposed to be about. If you weren't sure from all of the modding community's input that got included in the prior patch, well, here's some more for you. The community interaction is great from every angle, really... Modders get the recognition they deserve, average players get way more than they paid for, and the devs get a game that makes everyone that much happier.People here have mentioned the learning curve before, and it's there, but it's definitely not insurmountable... I know a handful of friends who've just tinkered with the game and gotten into low orbit around Kerbin and called it a day, but they're missing out on the real game. Each new task, each new challenge, requires you to master another skill in addition to properly executing everything else you've already learned. But when you finally get it right? There's a sense of accomplishment that's hard to find in any other game. Getting into orbit, changing orbits, landing, attempting a rendezvous, intercepting a planet that'll take you 6 months just to reach--once you start to string all of it together, the results of your hard work speak for themselves.And like lots of other folks have also said, there's a great sense of accomplishment when you nail a difficult task... but the real hilarity of the game comes from those moments when you get things just a little bit wrong. KSP will satisfy all of your emotional needs. <3But if you're more into stories, here's the highlight reel from my last playthrough after they updated Career Mode...The infamous Jebediah Kerman did most of my early test flights and managed to hog all of the glory. Not to be outdone, Bill Kerman booked a spot to be the first Kerbal to land on the Mun. UNFORTUNATELY, Bill botched the landing and his pod tipped over sideways and couldn't seem to right itself. Now we had a problem--not only was Bill stranded, but we hadn't yet researched a 2+ command pod that would allow for a rescue team.So the heroic Bill Kerman sat in his command pod, on the surface of Mun, eating snacks, for exactly 34 days while we built a ship big enough to take him home and got it to the landing site. We all held our breath as the ship arrived and prayed that Bill was still alive and had enough snacks.Jebediah stole the show again and came to the rescue, and got Bill into their 2-kerbal lander and got them back into space. BUT THEN, something happened.They ran out of gas. Before they got home.The lander collapsed into orbit around Kerbin, with enough fuel to get them off the Mun but not enough to finish the job. So now Bill AND Jeb were stuck in space for another 61 days while we engineered an unmanned ship that could grab them and redirect them to Kerbin's surface. Thankfully, by now, Bill's snacks had been replenished from the latest rescue attempt, and they hunkered down in anticipation of the final rescue attempt.Only... it wasn't the final rescue attempt. Being our first effort at a rendezvous in space, the unmanned ship with the grabby-claw came to within 3km of Bill and Jeb... and then rocketed straight past them into the unknown. It would be almost another month before we set out again.So we sent a SECOND ship with a BETTER grabby-claw, and THIS TIME WE GOT THEM. Our two heroes were yanked from orbit and rocketed home once and for all, splashing down just a short distance from where it all began.*..... This could happen to you. Buy it now.42/10 WILL DEFINITELY RUN OUT OF GAS AGAIN*Story based on real events, see screenshot library for documentation*

number of helpful: 10 of 15 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 24, 2015
												Oh my Science....This is... BY FAR....My favorite video game of the current era.Those who know me, know I'm a rabid Fallout and Resident Evil fangirl. I can't call this game my favorite yet (Fallout 2 still has this title by a steady grasp) but KSP is a very close follower.To sum up the entirety of this game in a few phrases or memes....This game = NASA + Lemmings.KSP is hollywood rocket science....collect ALL THE SCIENCE!There are 3 modes of play. The first mode is sandbox. You get all the parts unlocked, you can build anything you can think of, and then explode it marvellously while trying to fire it up into space. The second mode, is Science mode. This unlocks the Tech Tree and the collection of science. Parts are restricted by the Tech Tree, visitable through the R&D building. Collecting science unlocks branches in the Tech Tree. This gives you access to more and more parts, until you're eventually at the end of the tree, and its basically like Sandbox mode. The third is Career Mode. Career is the fully unlocked version of the game, requiring you to balance limited parts (locked behind the Tech Tree, requiring the collection of Science), limited money (Rocket science is expensive! Ships now cost money, and you have limited funding. In order to get more money, you need to complete missions from the Mission Control building), and spontaneous explosive deconstruction.The whole point of the game is to explore the Kerbol system. Its that simple. Build rockets, leave the planet Kerbin (third from the sun Kerbol), and visit all you can. The Kerbol System has 8 planets, Moho (like Mercury), Eve (Venus analogue), Kerbin (Earth-like), Duna (Mars rip-off), Dres (Small planet, light gravity, hard to land on), Jool (Jupiter wannabe), and Eeloo (Pluto if it was a planet!). Each planet has its own special features, moons, things to see, and difficulties in visiting.The game has an INCREDIBLE modding community, which I recommend, and the YouTube community loves making crafts and blowing them up. I VERY MUCH invite you to watch Scott Manley's videos for learning Kerbal science and aerodynamics.... skills needed to blow up much less often than before!The game still has its issues... I commonly find the Hell Kraken or♥♥♥♥♥Kraken (Community known bugs), but this may be due to the mods installed on my game.  The Windows x64 version is horribly broken, but the other versions are great.

number of helpful: 12 of 19 people (63%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 1, 2015
												I've been waiting patiently before reviewing this game and finally they released it so i can post my thoughts about it.The idea behind this game is amazing - you get to explore a solar system, build various rockets, pretend to be an engineer, a pilot or an explorer. They've managed to allow as much creativity as it actually possible at this current development level for simulation/strategy game.HOWEVER (it is a big however, i know) before you can actually enjoy anything like building a satellite to orbit around some distant planet, or a two way mission to the Mun - you will either have to learn hours and hours, and hours, and hours, even more hours of youtube tutorials or... cheat.When it comes to tutorials and explaining "how things work in the game we made" the developers failed so miserably, so utterly and completely, that you actually have to wonder which audience they intended this game for?Telling a new player to try and land a vehicle near space center - is not a tutorial. Forgetting to mention recently added features like heating and cooling, so they would inevitably burn in the atmosphere is a shocking oversight. Not mentioning how to save up fuel when launching vessels, changing orbits or de-orbiting is just lousy.Bottom line is - there is no comprehensive tutorial in this game whatsoever, no learning curve, no actually useful in game tips, tooltips or explanations on anything. Period.So before you actually can enjoy this game in its fullest (repetitively launching badly designed pieces of crap is just a part of it) - you will have to spend hours learning how the hell you can launch a vessel properly, save fuel, dock, transfer to another object, land, land in different atmosphere, land without an atmosphere, take off, etc. etc. etc.I was expecting them to completely revamp the tutorials and the learning curve - they did not. Because of that i was prepared to thumb it down but i could not. Even though developers clearly do not care about players actually getting into their game and enjoying it without wasting a lot of time - modders do care. There are mods that allow cheating, better parts and complete designs which reduce the difficulty curve significantly. There are also plenty of videos (i recommend Scott Manley) which explain various game aspects in details and manage to be both interesting and educational at the same time. So yeah... while i am very disappointed in developers, the community and modders made this game better, good enough to recommend it.

Early Access Review
								Stimulating, rewarding, enjoyable. KSP provides a Solar System and space technology similar to Earth's. Career mode gives an excellent context for performing "experiments"(go to place X and press button Y) to unlock better or different spaceship components, and has the freedom to let you choose what to attempt first, or go on free mode. Building a craft and putting it in orbit, going on to land a probe/rover/lander to a planet/moon feels fufilling. On the way doing spacewalks, crew reports, atmosphere/space experiments. It's a very involving game, solving the problems of how to reach a planet, slow down and land on it, and then get back. Ontop of being a fun game, KSP provides an easy way to grasp the concepts of space travel, and it's not overly complicated. Just pick the right parts, and fire your rocket at the right time and direction to get somewhere. Suffers a stuttering issue for many people, but it's not a gamebreaker.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 9, 2014
Early Access Review
								Kerbal space program is a physics sandbox space simulator. You can build ships or planes using individual parts such as engines, fuel tanks, solar panels etc. Planets are almost realistically sized and so is the space between them. You can build space stations, send probes to intercept the moon or some how build a manned base on the gas giant 'Jool'. If you ever get bored of the game then you can visit the space port website where you can download hundreds of modifications to the game, including physics changing ones!

content:
Posted: June 30, 2016
												With 80 hours invested into this game I can safely say it's amazing!KSP is an open sandbox space exploration simulator. Your role is a director that oversee the whole operation from fund management, hiring test dum- qualified astronauts, and building your ship design to hopefully reach space and beyond.Story wise this game doesn't have one. They career mode which is decent but it requires alot of grinding to unlock technology to advance your ship. As of my review this game has plenty of content but not enough interactive options. Such as my kerbals stats didn't much at all, no recoloring, or real purpose of exploration other then saying you did What this game lack is backed by a healthy molding community that put a sense of purpose to explore for resource, new ship design and energy source, and weapons!This game is abut trail and error. One mistake can cost a whole mission and most of my botch up mission ended a satisfying ball of fire and explosion. ProsEasy setup and understandExtreme replay valueConstant updatesExploration is satisfyingHealthy molding community ConsPlanet exploration has no real purpose without modsLack of customization other then shipsOverallPick up this game now, it is worth it at full price. This game to me spawn the whole idea of vehicle biudiling simulator with a purpose or mission.MSRP: $39.99Recommend Pick up Price: $39.99, and donate to Development!

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 1, 2014
Early Access Review
								  A review that should have come a long long time ago.  What can I say about Kerbal Space Program other than buy it.   Buy a copy for yourself, buy copies for your family memebers, and buy copies as gifts for your friends.     Hands down the best money on entertainment I have ever spent.  I've spent more hours than I care to admit to playing this gem of a game and in addition to the sheer joy and feelings of accomplishment this game gives its users you will also find yourself learning a ton about orbital mechanics in a fun and exciting way.   That feeling of accomplishment is so core to the Kerbal Space Program experience.  I can't think of a single KSP player who doesn't have a first docking story or loads of screenshots/videos from their first landing on another planet.  The list is endless with this game.    Another great part of the KSP experience is the community here and on the main forums.  The mod community is large and very active.  Mods for this title will blow you away!!!  So much so that some mods were swallowed up by the developers and the mod developers now work along side Squad.    If you have not yet bought this game I invite you to download the demo here on Steam or from www.KerbalSpaceProgram.com  After downloading the demo hit Youtube and grab some popcorn for the hours upon hours of tutorials and general fun surrounding this game.  If your anything like me it won't take but 5 minutes in the demo before you instantly see the value of this game.    Click buy!!!  You will not regret your purchase!!!!

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 22, 2013
												I have decided to edit my review, in light of (a TON) of new content since i last posted.------------Is the game fun:... its basically a drug.is it easy?: no.  not at all. in fact this will be the biggest issue people have with the game. while Dark souls is hard in a "quick reflexes or death" kind of way.... KSP is hard in a "omg i dont understand this, what on earth is a Pe and DeltaV?!" kind of way. One of the biggest issues new people to this game have is that well.... its rocket science. and most of us didn't walk into this game with a couple degrees. (though i feel like i could get one walking out)as a result there has been a huge disconnect for many people between the "what i need to know to enjoy this" and "what i actually know right now". amd this has caused many people to not enjoy there experience, or to quit the game altogether. Now with version 1.1, this issue has been addressed with an in game "wiki" if you will.  the rocket science 101, the up goers guide to the galaxy. and man did they hit it out of the park. not only is it super detailed.... i mean like, detailed enough that despite having 1500 hours logged in game on steam alone (dont judge me) i was still able to learn something i didn't know flipping its pages. but it is implemented in a way that makes it not only easy to access, and easy to use.... but basically screams "use me". right down to having a built in pause game button into the wiki, so you have the option of flipping a few pages on route to kill time... or to pause the game in a panic as you try to figure out why your 1 rocket just became 5.and yet, with all of that, its still super easy to follow.  I am glad they have finally cast away that looming shadow that has haunted this game for years and fixed one of the last real issues this game faced.and if you are wondering, yes.... the rest of the game is amazing too.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 20, 2013
												You know nothing about space.Don't you believe me?Try to reach the moon.Did you fail?Right, because you know nothing about space... yet...I'm in SPAAAaace ! This is by far the best space simulation game ever made, but forget space combat : the only fight will be your limited knowledge about space newtonian physics.The base game is very fun, and evolves with every new version in a most satisfying way. Then you can add community Plugins, and gods there are many good ones ! Create a communication network to pilot your probes around the solar system. Map the planets and asteroids to prepare your ground missions. Do science. Then create a gigantic asteroid mining base, a fuel reloading orbital station, and drive your ships even further on distant celestial objects.You will have to deal with the limitations of your science at the beginning to fulfill your contracts, but the more science you unlock, the further you will be able to go in your space odyssey.

content:
Posted: September 25, 2016
												Ok, first step... Build rocket, watch it explode.Second Step: Build rocket again, launch it, then watch it dive bomb into the ground/water/mountain....Third Step: Build rocket again, launch it, make it to the upper atmosphere and discover you didn't bring enough fuel....Fourth: Build rocket again, add more fuel, launch, and finally get it into orbit.....Fifth Step: Pass out from high blood pressure attack from actually getting into orbit and finding out you don't have enough fuel to return to the planet....Sixth Step: Look at the clock and discover you forgot to go to work, feed the cat, ect. Seveth Step: Return to step 1.Bloody love this game!  I acutally have more hours than posted, as I play this game on my laptop while on the road, usually at night so that I'm all stressed out.Now the Cons:[ ] Steep learning curve, unless you have high understanding of physic's, math, your already an Astronaut.[ ] An i5 Intel CPU (or AMD equal) or better recommended[ ] Lots of memory and graphics memory

content:
Posted: April 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								I can honestly say this is one of the most enjoyable games recently developed that I have ever seen. A steep learning curve means progress can be slow and difficult, but overcoming challenges become all the more rewarding as a result. You have the options to build spacecraft that are simple, complex, brilliant, insane, or a combination of all four. Then you get to fly what you've built and see whether you need to change the design, or merely how you fly it. With a community that is usually eager to help those who struggle, feedback and advice is seldom out of reach. I highly recommend this game if you're into space exploration and are not afraid of a challenge.

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 7, 2014
Early Access Review
								After one and half year since my last review at 0.25, I am pretty amazed about how this game has changed. Careers, more parts, better aerodynamics and heating simulation.What I loved better is the amazing modders. Plugins and parts are always growing better, taking shapes and functioning more smoothly. Ferram4, bac9, Acea, BahamutoD, those guys are just getting more amazing than ever making more and more fantastic mods.Since 1.1 is almost out of the bakery, this indie game is making it's way through!====Previous review at 0.25 [Sept.2014]====Well, after a total of 100 hours of gaming time (steam doesn't count every time I started it directly from the directory), I was proud to say that I am finally a amateur engineer and pilot. In the gaming process, I found this game quite challenging despite earlier easy experience. Generally, it's a pretty nice game though it's still in dev. Much of the game is something like Space Engineer, but this one is quite realistic(if you got some mods installed). Also, the game's setting is a highlight. A vast system of star, planets, asteroids and moons. Impressive if you like exploring. Also, the orbit and aerodynamic is just as great as its inspiring game, Orbiter. The game is developed on Unity platform, and the x64 edition is just realeased and packed with some bugs, severe or unimportant. If it simply crashed or a Oops message appears, don't worry. It's just a bug ruining your game experience. But don't blame the dev team please! They are trying their best to make everything perfect, although it's just a "Good" now. Oh, and one more thing, this game is finally entering BETA testing! Mark the day on the calendar, Jeb! You'll never forget it! So that is it, the game for a sandbox gamer, a rocket maniac or a airplane designer; even worse with the 0.25 update, it is also suitable for a sociopath who liked to design and destroy things.  Thousands of mods are available in the official forum[forum.kerbalspaceprogram.com]. If you are intrested in it, try out the demo in the official site[www.kerbalspaceprogram.com].In a few words, this game worths the price.

content:
Posted: June 20, 2014
Early Access Review
								I really love this game. It is like you are NASA and all of its employees. You get to design and build the rockets, spaceships, and planes and then fly them. I am currently doing missions to explore and land on the moons of what would be Jupiter in the game, and I can still see a lot of content left for me to explore. Once you get into the game a bit, I highly suggest looking into downloading some mods for the game, since it has a pretty strong modding community. This game teaches you geometry, planetary motion, the effects of gravity in space and much, much more. I find myself using my calculator to plan my missions and drawing up mission outlines. Success in the game takes a smart mind and a good plan. I think it is one of the best games I have ever played.I highly recommed it.

number of helpful: 5 of 6 people (83%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: May 25, 2015
												Possibly one of the best games to be released in the last 10 years. I have for a very long time dreamed of going to space and this game only strengthen's that desire. Here's my analysis of this game.Graphics: Have improved dramatically compared to what they were back when I started playing. The Mun has changed shape for crying out loud!Gameplay: With the recently improved aerodynamics, The gameplay is superb. Watching your own rocket/spaceplane tumble back to Kerbin is an amazing feeling.Other: Contracts are wonderful. However, they feel a little repetitive in the late game. The tech tree is fun to explore and great for first time players. When multiplayer comes out I wont be surprised if I rack up 2000+ hours on here. If I were a therapist I would recommend this game to my patients because of how great you feel when you finally land on the Mun that required 5 Kerbal's lives to get there, and then planning a rescue mission!The rundown: Buy this immediately.

								I. Love. Dis. Game.  It has quite a harsh learning curve, i tossed this game aside after 10-20 failed launches, But when i came back a week or two later, I put some time into it. The list of mods for this game are endless with some of the more well known being MechJeb(Good for Newbie) K9, Kethane, Extended rocket packs. etc etc, Massive list.  I find myself starting a new game every couple weeks just because a lot can be done differently, I tend to try keep my place clean, Place a flag everywhere i go. Run out of fuel and end up stranded. Send rescue missions. A lot of what this game has to offer comes down to ones own willingness to make it themselves lol.  A few great YouTubers for KSP but i absolutely love Scott Manley, I've picked up a lot of things from watching his video's.  Regardless!, Excellent game, and i intend to play to play it for a long time to come. 10/10

Posted: May 29, 2015
												What a fantastic game!I have been playing since early beta and had the pleasure of watching this game blossom into what it is today.If you enjoy building and tinkering, planes and rockets, space exploration, and many, many explosions, then this game is definitely for you!You have the pleasure of building the Kerbal Space Program from the ground up. Starting from your very first rocket exploding on the pad, you will soon be taking your Kerbals to distant planets with full blown multi-stage ships, and planning trans orbital maneuvers like you had been doing it all your life.If I were new to KSP, I think my only complaint would be the lack of a thorough tutorial. The player is really left to fend for themselves as far as using features goes. There is a lot to learn about controlling and building your craft, and most of it has to be done by trial and error. Fortunately there are plenty of community resources for KSP, so a short Google search will get you past any features you are having trouble with. This game will certainly be a joy to play. Definitely recommended for anyone with a mind to download it.

content:
Posted: January 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								If you like to "win" games, this game is not for you. If however, you like to "play" games, this is your game. This is a simluation much like SimCity, in that it is what you make out of it. Just like most simluations, you have a carreer mode, in which you start off with nothing much but a rocket, a pod an some gadgets to learn science. As you explore more and more science, you open up more and more rockets, winglets and more science gadgets. I have to tell you the truth, games like this, Civ5 Simcity, i dont play EVERYDAY. This game sat in my steam shelf for a few months, but once I do start playing them, I go on 20-50hr binges....Im on one of those now :) Get this game if you like fun and science, do the tutorials to get an idea of what you CAN do, and just have fun!

content:
Posted: January 27, 2015
Early Access Review
								It's a game about orbital mechanics. Who knew science could be so much fun?Admittedly, I was a bit relunctant to purchase due to "early access" stigma or something along those lines. Glad I did! If you like science, sandboxes, space, and blowing♥♥♥♥♥♥up with moar boosters, this is for you.There's a sizable learning curve, sure, but don't let that put you off (it took me close to 70 hours in to get good enough at docking) KSP has one of the best, if not THE best community hands down. On top of that, there's the legendary Scott Manley on YouTube who has extensive knowledge and makes things crystal clear. Once you figure out the fundamentals in this game, things become quite a bit easier and you can really let your creativity run loose.Also, this game can help you learn about orbital mechanics. KSP has helped tremendously with giving my interest in science a much needed boost. Then there's the mods. The wonderful folk who make mods spend lots of time seamlessly integrating them into KSP.Chances are, if there's something you desire in KSP that doesn't exist just yet, there's a mod for it, or being currently made. When I started playing with mods, it opened up so many doors for creativity. In short, KSP offers a lot. Especially as an early access title, and compared to a lot of AAA titles being released.I think Squad will become one of the best devs out there. I recommend this over and over again.Uh. BUY IT.

content:
Posted: November 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								Pros:+Totally open ended, build whatever sort of rockets you like.+Persistent universe, rockets you send up today can serve as docking platforms or refueling stations for things you send tomorrow.+Fun cartoon aesthetic.+Built-in procedural quest system (Contracts) always available to give you new goals.  They're totally optional, you can fly wherever your fuel will take you.+This game taught me orbital mechanics.Cons:-Rough optimization.  You may need a beefy rig especially if you want to make big complicated rockets.  However a small rocket can complete most of the in game challenges and is kinder on your system.-Control scheme can take some getting used to.  Everything is rebindable though.-Dedication to realism means that you're sometimes hitting the time compression button and waiting (and waiting) for an orbital launch window to open.  However this is only an issue for distant planets.  The moon is always nearby and ready to explore.This game doesn't hold your hand because there's not one (or even ten) correct answers to any problem.  You may find certain tasks like getting a stable orbit or docking with another craft challenging, but there's literally hundreds of cheerful, informative youtube vids offering tips.  And if it starts hard, you'll feel like a boss when you finally nail it.

content:
Posted: January 7
												This game looks simplistic at first glance but may be one of the best space/rocket simulators out there. Even though we're not launching real humans into space, the premise will grab your attention. Launch everything from simple rockets into orbit to landing onto other planets. A warning to the player though, this game is not easy when it comes to getting where you want to go. The game is fun but comes with a huge learning curve called orbital mechanics.Kerbal Space Program is a rocket simulator. The objectives change as the player progresses through the game depending what game mode was chosen. There are 3 modes : science, career and sandbox. Career is the real challenge as reputation, contracts, money and research all play a crucial role in completing objectives and acquiring better technology to build better rockets. Science throws aside the funds and reputation but still respects research in which the player still needs to meet certain objectives. Sandbox lets the player run loose without any strings attached and even has some pre-loaded vessels ready to be launched. Do not be fooled though, this game isn't as easy as launching into the sky and flying to another planet. There are a lot of calculations involved and for me personally, a lot of youtube tutorial videos. Adding all the components you wish to isn't always easy, and definitely isn't easy to launch all that off the planet!There are a few primary structures that start small and grow (visually) as the player progresses. These structures include a vehicle assembly building, launch pad, space plane hangar, runway, tracking station, and astronaut complex. The vehicle assembly building is where the rocket, ship or even lander can be assembled and saved/loaded. The Hangar is for planes that need to take off on the runway. The tracking station is for data, mission management and tracking statistics (such as where landed ships are). Lastly, the astronaut complex allows the player to recruit new units to fly into space. Each structure can be upgraded by clicking the right mouse button. Other structures include research and development (which is important to improving and discovering new parts), mission control used to obtain contracts and the administration building, I'm not too sure what it does.Building in Kerbal Space Program is relative simple and easy to do. The challenge is finding something that works and doesn't blow up during launch. The trick is not only to be able to pilot it without it spinning out of control but also have enough fuel to land. The first part comes easy to me but the second part is actually quite difficult if take off isn't done properly. There are a tonne of parts that the word limit on this review won't let me name them all. Parts included are parachutes, cockpits, aerodynamic wings, de-couplers, rocket-fuel boosters, fuel canisters, biology bays, research attachments, and all sorts of other thrusters and boosters. To add more depth to the construction, frames can be added to the rocket so that the rocket doesn't need to stand on it's own boosters. Meaning, if you have a rocket that can't really stand on it's own due to it's odd shape, size and weight, there is a method to suspend the rocket in the air prior to launch. Releasing the rocket is relatively easy but ensure that you place everything in proper order. Order is especially important in this game and can be easily overlooked when constructing. If you don't put everything in sequential firing order, you just might fire the wrong rockets and cause an accident. Order (or stages) are everything! Double checking this will definitely save some headaches.Visually the game is basic but ensures details where necessary. The rocket parts are pretty detailed but the world itself sort of feels bland. I do feel they could have added a little bit more to the terrain (or added some cities) to make it more... decorative. What is cool is that they decided to include a camera on-board every shuttle. So whether you're flying one Kerbal or many, you can check their facial expressions at any time (which is a neat feature). The sounds are basic and do provide the essentials but nothing extremely out of the ordinary. Crash effects are definitely included.Overall, good game but with a big learning curve. Don't jump into this expecting to hit the moon right away. It will require some skill, observation and background. When you do succeed and understand how it works the game, everything becomes a lot easier to do (obviously)! It's just getting through the learning stage is what makes it difficult. For future updates or games, I would recommend trying to make an "easier" setting so regulars can simply jump in and play. Then again, the challenge is what attracted so many players.RATING : 7.95/10 Gameplay A- Story / Campaign B Visuals / User Interface C+ Sounds / Music C+ Replay-ability B- Overall  BScreenShots : [url][/url][url][/url]

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 30, 2013
Early Access Review
								Kerbal Space Program is by far one of the greatest games I have played in my life. From the cute expressions on the Kerbal's faces to the excitement of landing one of your creations on an alien world - this game delivers. I'd like to start out by saying..holy♥♥♥♥♥♥ There are many, many planets and moons to land on with many, many parts to and combinations to do it with. You can make Rovers, Space Stations, Vehicles to transport your little, green friends; you name it. The planets are all really, really awesome and vast. You could spend hundreds, even thousands of hours exploring a single planet/moon. Things never get boring!  Don't think for a minute that tasting the fruits of your labor will be easy, though. The game is a very difficult game to master and will take you plenty of time just to get the basics down. There's a steep learning curve, but in the end it's worth it. Whether you make it to one of the many bodies or you end up exploding half way through the atmosphere of Kerbin, it's satisfying! Seeing your creation shatter into a million pieces and then watching them rain down onto kerbin is just...I mean...glorious. The game is still in development, so it's pretty buggy. To be honest though, you'll get over it when you successfully land on the moon for the first time. Another thing is the fact that the game is a bit of a resource hog, meaning you have to have a decent computer to play this game to it's potential. It's still playable with a semi-low/medium end computer, but things will be a wee bit slow at times, especially with larger part counts. But really, aside from that I don't really have anything negative to say about the game. Go ahead and buy it, you will not regret it.

content:
Posted: March 21, 2015
Early Access Review
								My daughters boyfriend turned me onto the Kerbal Space Program last week.  OMG, I can't remember the last time I was so sucked into a game..... wait, game???   No, this is not just a game, it's way more. I've played plenty of Outer Space games, and most are just 1st or 3rd person shooters of some form.  But not this.  For the first time I can remember, the Kerbal Space Program lets you sink your teeth into real problems with space travel, like gravity and establishing orbits!  It's much harder than one might first think...... which I love!!!This is not a game for people that want to shoot and blow up stuff. This is a game for science and math geeks who like some serious hardcore problem solving.  It's not Rocket Science.... Oh wait.... yes it is!!!
