content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
Early Access Review
								Definitely my most favourite game of this 2013, and it's not even finished yet!The idea is to make spacecraft to explore the solar system. Sounds simple, right?There are two basic game modes, Career and Sandbox. In sandbox mode you get all the pieces to play with, and can design anything you can conceive with the parts available to take you as far as you like. This is how I started playing the game and it provided hours of entertainment and explosions, but it does rely to an extent on setting your own goals. See if you can get to the Mun. Then Minmus. Land on each one. Get to other planets. Make a space station. It goes on!Career mode was recently introduced and definitely simplifies the learning curve a lot, limiting your starting builds and unlocking parts through performing science, and adds a lot of value to the experience, as well as adding a purpose for some of the parts that seem to be pointless in sandbox mode. Finally, the modding community is extremely active for this game with mods to add mineable resources, expand part lists, and adding new methods of travelling (warp anyone?), and even a multiplayer mod still in its infancy. Without a doubt the best value for money in terms of time played for me.

content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
												One of my favourite games of all time... back when it still was in Early Access with version number 0.23 or 0.24.2. After that pretty much all the developers have done is integrating some mods and putting boobs on a kerbal (but no boob-physics, so you can't study how boobs jiggle in space. So what's the point of female kerbals. Except to push the feminist ideology down your throat.)Also I'm a Sandbox-guy, who doesn't give a damn about Career or Science mode (Though I'm also the only guy in the community who ♥♥♥♥ing hates Jebediah Kerman, or any one of those orange suited kerbals), just let me fly planes and spaceships.But enough of ranting. In a nutshell this is a game where you build stuff and then crash them. Rovers, Planes, Rockets, Starships, whatever you desire. Also Satellites, Space Stations and unmanned probes.Graphics may not be the best there are, but that doesn't stop the game from being mindblowingly stunning. The first time you achieve orbit (it's not that hard) and look down. If you enjoyed Gravity or Interstellar in theaters, you'll like this game. Though even with all the new nuisances I still recommend this game as it still is pretty fun.Just make sure you get some mods.Install one mod and start your own asteroid mining corporation.Another mod and start colonizing other worlds.Third one and you got yourself an Apollo 11 replica.Fourth mod to build a bloody Borg cube.Fifth, sixth and seventh for GPS system, Deep Space Telescope and a Mapping satellite.The list goes on and on.And now, I'm off to the internet to find a previous version of this game along with some compatible mods and without female kerbals.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 30, 2015
												A thoroughly enjoyable simulation game.  Check out my full video review:


YouTube™ Video: Kerbal Space Program: A Bird's Eye View (Game Review) 

			Views: 17		

			Endeavor (@endeavor_rg) explores the strange world of Kerbal Space Program. Developer: Squad Publisher: Squad Steam Page: http://store.steampowered.com/app/220200/ This video's backing music is...		

Video Transcript:Hello viewers!  Welcome to another episode of A Bird's Eye View.  My name is Endeavor, once again your humble host.  Our game this time is the simulator Kerbal Space Program.  Developed and published by Squad, this game came out of Early Access in April of 2015.  Let's take a look at the finished product.As a simulation game, Kerbal Space Program doesn't have a real story to speak of.  The player is tasked with running a NASA like organization made up of accident-prone green people called Kerbals.  Administrator duties include everything from securing funding, designing ships, and even personally piloting space shuttles, all the while trying to keep your astronauts alive long enough to go on more than one mission.The game has a charmingly simple atmosphere, with unobtrusive, upbeat music to keep the mood light.  Most of the engine is dedicated to simulating complex physics, so the art is fairly plain.  The graphical limitations are fine since the ultimate purpose of the game is to tinker around with creative spaceship crafting.Kerbal Space Program includes a few game modes.  The primary way to play is called Career Mode, which unpacks the game slowly, constantly giving the player new challenges to beat in order to unlock more things with which to play.  Sandbox, which used to be the main game, gives the player all of the unlockable ship parts to use right off the bat.  Finally, there’s Science Mode, which includes missions and tasks like Career Mode, but without some of the more managerial duties like worrying about funding.The controls, while not simple, are consistent enough, and they can be rebound for ease-of-use.  There were so many controls and commands to remember that I had to reference the options menu frequently, but the game doesn't punish the player for doing so.There are games with annoyingly overzealous tutorials that constantly remind the player how to do things.  Kerbal Space Program is not one of those.  Quite honestly, while the tutorials are comprehensive, they throw so much technical jargon and complex concepts at the player that the tutorials feel inadequate.  This game doesn't hold your hand, and I'm left with the impression that the player is expected to crash and burn a few times before getting it.One part of the game that sorely needed further explanation was the Career Mode.  The game tells you that you need to launch missions and conduct research to earn Science (a sort of currency for unlocking upgrades), but almost no effort was made explaining how one conducts research.  I learned more about how to play from Wikis and online guides than I did from the game itself.There were only a few bugs which I encountered during my time.  When building, there were a few times where the ship pieces wouldn't attach to the spacecraft how I wanted them to.  Fixing the issue involved saving my work and reloading, which wasn't a big deal, but it happened often enough to warrant a mention here.  A few times I had a problem where ship pieces that were meant to separate during flight wouldn't cooperate, dooming my ship and mission to an explosive end.Despite any issues I had with the game, I think it was masterfully put together.  Nothing beats the feeling of finally getting your ship out of the atmosphere for the first time, and the accomplishments don't stop there.  Once you've broken the speed and altitude records, it's time to orbit the planet Kerbal.  And then try landing a ship on the moon.  Learning to manage limited fuel supplies and using gravitational pull to slingshot around planets and moons is fascinatingly complex, yet the satisfaction in learning all of the ins and outs of space travel make it a worthwhile endeavor.The game's retail price is $39.99.  With all of the features and science-based entertainment, I recommend Kerbal Space Program for anyone that loves building and discovery.  It's currently available on Steam and Good Old Games for Windows, Mac, and Linux.  It is also available for PS4.That concludes my review for Kerbal Space Program.  Thank you for watching, and don't forget to hit the “like” button if you enjoyed my video.  As always, you can follow us on Twitter at Rookery Gamers for let's plays and additional reviews.

content:
Posted: July 30, 2015
												A thoroughly enjoyable simulation game.  Check out my full video review:


YouTube™ Video: Kerbal Space Program: A Bird's Eye View (Game Review) 

			Views: 17		

			Endeavor (@endeavor_rg) explores the strange world of Kerbal Space Program. Developer: Squad Publisher: Squad Steam Page: http://store.steampowered.com/app/220200/ This video's backing music is...		

Video Transcript:Hello viewers!  Welcome to another episode of A Bird's Eye View.  My name is Endeavor, once again your humble host.  Our game this time is the simulator Kerbal Space Program.  Developed and published by Squad, this game came out of Early Access in April of 2015.  Let's take a look at the finished product.As a simulation game, Kerbal Space Program doesn't have a real story to speak of.  The player is tasked with running a NASA like organization made up of accident-prone green people called Kerbals.  Administrator duties include everything from securing funding, designing ships, and even personally piloting space shuttles, all the while trying to keep your astronauts alive long enough to go on more than one mission.The game has a charmingly simple atmosphere, with unobtrusive, upbeat music to keep the mood light.  Most of the engine is dedicated to simulating complex physics, so the art is fairly plain.  The graphical limitations are fine since the ultimate purpose of the game is to tinker around with creative spaceship crafting.Kerbal Space Program includes a few game modes.  The primary way to play is called Career Mode, which unpacks the game slowly, constantly giving the player new challenges to beat in order to unlock more things with which to play.  Sandbox, which used to be the main game, gives the player all of the unlockable ship parts to use right off the bat.  Finally, there’s Science Mode, which includes missions and tasks like Career Mode, but without some of the more managerial duties like worrying about funding.The controls, while not simple, are consistent enough, and they can be rebound for ease-of-use.  There were so many controls and commands to remember that I had to reference the options menu frequently, but the game doesn't punish the player for doing so.There are games with annoyingly overzealous tutorials that constantly remind the player how to do things.  Kerbal Space Program is not one of those.  Quite honestly, while the tutorials are comprehensive, they throw so much technical jargon and complex concepts at the player that the tutorials feel inadequate.  This game doesn't hold your hand, and I'm left with the impression that the player is expected to crash and burn a few times before getting it.One part of the game that sorely needed further explanation was the Career Mode.  The game tells you that you need to launch missions and conduct research to earn Science (a sort of currency for unlocking upgrades), but almost no effort was made explaining how one conducts research.  I learned more about how to play from Wikis and online guides than I did from the game itself.There were only a few bugs which I encountered during my time.  When building, there were a few times where the ship pieces wouldn't attach to the spacecraft how I wanted them to.  Fixing the issue involved saving my work and reloading, which wasn't a big deal, but it happened often enough to warrant a mention here.  A few times I had a problem where ship pieces that were meant to separate during flight wouldn't cooperate, dooming my ship and mission to an explosive end.Despite any issues I had with the game, I think it was masterfully put together.  Nothing beats the feeling of finally getting your ship out of the atmosphere for the first time, and the accomplishments don't stop there.  Once you've broken the speed and altitude records, it's time to orbit the planet Kerbal.  And then try landing a ship on the moon.  Learning to manage limited fuel supplies and using gravitational pull to slingshot around planets and moons is fascinatingly complex, yet the satisfaction in learning all of the ins and outs of space travel make it a worthwhile endeavor.The game's retail price is $39.99.  With all of the features and science-based entertainment, I recommend Kerbal Space Program for anyone that loves building and discovery.  It's currently available on Steam and Good Old Games for Windows, Mac, and Linux.  It is also available for PS4.That concludes my review for Kerbal Space Program.  Thank you for watching, and don't forget to hit the “like” button if you enjoyed my video.  As always, you can follow us on Twitter at Rookery Gamers for let's plays and additional reviews.

content:
Posted: January 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								This game is truly amazing. As a kid, I've always dreamed of becoming a pilot, of a spaceplane or airplane, and this game lets me play with the realistic aerodynamics/physics of air/space travel, and it does it right.....oh, and it's still in beta! Except for minor glitches here and there, this game is perfect and VERY well made. It lets you build any rocket/spaceplane/airplane you want and fly it to distant planets/celestial bodies, land and return, all to complete missions to get more science, which you can use to unlock upgrades for your vehicles. Right now, I've made the sexiest spaceplane you can imagine, which can get into orbit around Kerbin (home planet), transmit data and return back to base, in perfect shape. Kinda like an upgrade of the Space Shuttle (since it doesn't need external boosters to get into orbit).See, this game is extremely realistic, so you get to learn a lot about the exact orbital mechanics NASA workers are required to know. I used to think getting into space was just firing a rocket straight up, but realistically, you need to have a high surface velocity so you can get into orbit, otherwise, you're wasting a ton of fuel on either flying far away from home or falling back to the earth due to gravity. There isn't zero gravity once you leave the atmosphere, that's only because there's just as much gravity the other way, due to your orbit in which you're constantly falling, but have a high enough velocity to generate an equal G-force the in the opposite direction. And if you want to go to the Mun (moon), you'll need to use your orbit to slingshot yourself to the place where you and the Mun moon will be at the same time, since you must take into account that the Mun also moves in an orbit. I swear, you'll learn a TON about orbital physics, as well as you'll have a lot of fun building your spaceship however you want. And if it crashes to the ground, you must think about which part was misplaced to cause the crash, getting you in this trial and error loop until you FINALLY fix up the whole thing perfectly. Then you can think of its purpose-transport vessel, science lab, satellite launcher or a long distance traveler to a distant celestial body etc. etc. There's so much science to do, so many new ideas to think of and so much to learn from this game. Get the game and prepare to ignore every other game you have in your library because this game is out of this world! (literally)

content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
												One of my favourite games of all time... back when it still was in Early Access with version number 0.23 or 0.24.2. After that pretty much all the developers have done is integrating some mods and putting boobs on a kerbal (but no boob-physics, so you can't study how boobs jiggle in space. So what's the point of female kerbals. Except to push the feminist ideology down your throat.)Also I'm a Sandbox-guy, who doesn't give a damn about Career or Science mode (Though I'm also the only guy in the community who ♥♥♥♥ing hates Jebediah Kerman, or any one of those orange suited kerbals), just let me fly planes and spaceships.But enough of ranting. In a nutshell this is a game where you build stuff and then crash them. Rovers, Planes, Rockets, Starships, whatever you desire. Also Satellites, Space Stations and unmanned probes.Graphics may not be the best there are, but that doesn't stop the game from being mindblowingly stunning. The first time you achieve orbit (it's not that hard) and look down. If you enjoyed Gravity or Interstellar in theaters, you'll like this game. Though even with all the new nuisances I still recommend this game as it still is pretty fun.Just make sure you get some mods.Install one mod and start your own asteroid mining corporation.Another mod and start colonizing other worlds.Third one and you got yourself an Apollo 11 replica.Fourth mod to build a bloody Borg cube.Fifth, sixth and seventh for GPS system, Deep Space Telescope and a Mapping satellite.The list goes on and on.And now, I'm off to the internet to find a previous version of this game along with some compatible mods and without female kerbals.

content:

Early Access Review
NASA simulator 2013You're stuck on a earth like planet without trees or life at all called Kerbin. The only people left is a group of small green men who call themselves Kerbals. Nobody know how they got here, or how long they've been here. (Kraken!). It's no wonder that their biggest goal in life is to reach distant planets in search for whatever that they wish to find.Your task, is to help these poor, *ehm* brave! Soldiers into the battle of the unknown sandbox, un?-limited, blackness above them. ALL IN THE NAME OF SCIENCE!Trust me! IT'S AWSOME!You can basically do whatever space stuff you want. Wanna go to the Mün? Then do!Wanna build a space station? Then do!Wanna fly a plane? Then do!What about SSTO? Feel free!Kill Kerbals? Yeees...? *ehm* sadist!Drive a rover? Yes! Please!Build a huge rocket? YES! We all do!Go EVA? Sure thing, just don't get lost ;3  What I write What is it   Mün Kerbins inner Moon   SSTO Single stage to orbit   EVA Extravehicular activity (AKA: Spacewalk)

content:
Posted: June 1, 2016
												AMAZING game. Do you like flying? Do you like space? Ever wanted to build planes and spaceships? Then allow yourself. I\'ve learned so much about launching crafts into orbit, getting to planets, the calculations, OH what I have learned. And the fun I\'ve had while doing it! You\'ll spend a half an hour building a spacecraft and making sure its 100% set and ready to get put into orbit and complete its objective. Then you\'ll get to launch and control your craft through the atmosphere and into the galaxy laid out before you. Two moons orbit your planet, more planets lay beyond yours, each with different gravity and temperatures and atmospheres.If you want a game about space and building your own craft and controlling them? Do it. SO worth it. I\'ve even found making my own jets and flying within the atmosphere fun and educational all in one. If you have a creative kid, or one who loves spaces? Do it.It has a sandbox mode, build and fly whatever you want, or you can take on missions and slowly proceed through the various parts and completing different objectives.Downsides? Only jets for inner atmosphere, no propellers in the vanilla game (with mods you can get some, but they aren\'t 100%), no submarine crafts to my knowledge, but \"water craft\" and seaplanes... errr seajets are able to be made.Overall 100%, get it! Try it out at the very least!

								Do you like science?  Like armchair aeronautics?  Like watching rockets fail catastrophically in an effort to reach orbit?  Buy this game.In the game, you get to assemble rockets/space planes from a decent list of parts and then launch/pilot them and see how they perform.  Aeronautic forces are actually at work on your designs and you have to consider center of lift/gravity and things like weight and thrust.  There are moons/other planets to explore in a sandbox environment.  If you like building things and tinkering around with them, you'll love this game.

content:
Posted: May 22, 2013
Early Access Review
								This game requires a surprising amount of dedication just to enter. The learning curve is an immediate cliff off of the get-go, however I think it is most certaintly worth the effort. The core of the game is simple (ironic as it is still relatively complex) orbital physics; not exactly a common skill or knowledge. This isn't necessarily big issue, as the game works for how much you put into it. If all you want is large explosions and awkward rockets with no real effort, go at it. If you want to spend hours perfectly calculating how the rocket will work, the game provides the information to do so.The community is great for the game, as the steep learning curve keeps the stereotypical "haters" or "trolls" away from the subreddit or forums. Even when I started playing (about 2 years ago, 9 major updates total) there were more tutorials and mods than I could ever use. Their quality has since skyrocketed (pun intended), and never ceases to amaze me.The goal of the game? Right now there is a career mode, where you manage funds and reputation with limited parts, however you can fulfill contracts and complete objectives to gain new parts and money. There is another mode without the currency system, and then there is the original sandbox mode where anything goes, everything is free.Other than that the game is mostly self-driven. For me, it's the challenge of the game. When I started, landing on the moon was about as far away as, well, the moon. Now I usually spend my time making orbital stations or interplanetary landers using the plethora of mods available (my favorites including b9, remotetech 2, and KAS).The game is almost like a puzzle, if you will; a very, very open-ended puzzle. Massive, towering rockets that take your brave kerbals to the outer reaching planets can perform the same as tiny, lightweight and efficient rockets with a small probe. If I had to rate it, I would definitely give it a 10/10 for the experience it's given me thus far; and so far I haven't lost interest.

content:
Posted: October 9, 2014
Early Access Review
								I was absolutely addicted to this game when I first picked it up, and honestly I can’t wait to kick my Space Engineers addiction and get back to my Kerbals!I think it would be hard to describe the deep mechanics of this game without making it sound rather dry and educational, but as a huge fan of astronomy and the idea of space travel, I think this is a game everyone should give a go. Contrary to how some of the screen shots and discussion threads may appear, you don’t need an engineering degree to get something out of KSP. While the simulation aspect is very flushed out (and frequently being updated and fine tuned) there is enough arcade inspiration to allow for silly builds and brute force approaches to reach goals. At the same time however, those with a knack for math and engineering, your precision and dedication will be rewarded with epic adventures across the Kerbal Solar System.Kerbal Space Program is a must buy in my book!

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is easily one of the best indie games you can get your filthy moondust covered hands on.Although the learning curve in the beginning is pretty steep for someone who isn't aware of basic orbital physics or is on par with the navball or rocket construction, it's nothing a couple of videos from Scott Manley (or Robbaz if you intend to just make space a circus) can't fix. If you however know what you are doing and/or have been following someone who knows what they're doing you should have no problem at all getting into this game.It features many planets, their moons and in the future even an asteroid belt you'll be able to interact with all from the comfort of your own room/NASA mission control centre.You can build everything from rockets, space planes, landers, probes and god knows what.The game also features modding support and mods for the game can be found on the KSP site. Mods can add everything from boat parts, weapons, tools for making robots and mechs, new parts to add to the already pretty big library of parts and even customized planets.The game is however somewhat unstable and building large stations etc can often cause horrible lag on all but the beefiest computers, it is however only a problem when you build VERY large stuff and once the game is finished the optimization will no doubt be better than it currently is.I truly recommend this game to any and all of you! There is something for pretty much everyone in this game, if there isn't then mods have probably added it.If your PC can run this game, I see no reason for you not buying it. Trust me the game is worth every penny but if it's on a sale you pretty much have to buy it. Your life is not complete without this game. Get it now. Seriously.

content:
Posted: January 12
												10/10 crash simulator.Seriously though, this game is fantastic if you don't mind the steep learning curve, kerbals who can survive high falls, learning about space and failing...A lot of failing. “I have not failed. I've just found 10,000 ways that won't work.” Who doesn't love failing? What was I doing? Oh yeah, my ship just crashed and burned, back to the VAB. Flight's going well? Alt-tab and come back 5s later, well look who's on their way down to the cold hard ground. But really, failing is just a part of the game, and you get to learn what works and what doesn't. It gets much better once you understand the concepts required to handle and build the vehicles as well as space exploration in general. Then you go on building things that just works and it really gives a sense of achievement; you did it, you. You got Bob up in space. Great job, now he's stranded...because all you wanted was to get to space and you forgot to include the return trip. The game supports mods to enhance the experience, features several modes depending on what you want to do. Play sandbox if you want to build ridiculous rockets with enough funds to run an entire nation just to have it crash into mission control 5 seconds later as you laugh manically. Science for those who do not want to manage funds but still go through the science develoment and career for the management of all aspects of building your own space program.  Also remember that F5 is your best friend. It's the only one who can come clutch for you when all else seem to fall apart.

content:
Posted: December 27, 2016
												Kerbal Space Program is one of the best games ever made (If you don't mind playing it alone.) I've but more than 1200 hours into it, and I can say it has captures my imagination more than anything has since I started playing Minecraft back in high school. This game is educational, imaginative, addictive, optimized, and never ever leaves you with nothing to do. Space flight is immersive, realistic, and exciting. No other game has ever given a player the experience of building a rocket, launching it, and flying it to the moon and back with absolutely no loading screen. Literally billions of meters, no loading screen. If you have even a vague interest in space flight, engineering, or exploration, KSP is for you. And on top of the fantastic vanilla game, there is an active and thriving modding community that elevated the game to new heights. Like Minecraft, if you can think of it, there is a mod of it. Want to build a scale Saturn V and head to the full-scale moon. There's a mod for that. Want to create a colony, completely from your own design, there a mod for that. Want to shoot rockets at enemy mechs on mars? There is a mod for that. Best game ever. Best mods ever. 10/10. KSP for president.

number of helpful: 3 of 3 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 22, 2013
Early Access Review
								This game requires a surprising amount of dedication just to enter. The learning curve is an immediate cliff off of the get-go, however I think it is most certaintly worth the effort. The core of the game is simple (ironic as it is still relatively complex) orbital physics; not exactly a common skill or knowledge. This isn't necessarily big issue, as the game works for how much you put into it. If all you want is large explosions and awkward rockets with no real effort, go at it. If you want to spend hours perfectly calculating how the rocket will work, the game provides the information to do so.The community is great for the game, as the steep learning curve keeps the stereotypical "haters" or "trolls" away from the subreddit or forums. Even when I started playing (about 2 years ago, 9 major updates total) there were more tutorials and mods than I could ever use. Their quality has since skyrocketed (pun intended), and never ceases to amaze me.The goal of the game? Right now there is a career mode, where you manage funds and reputation with limited parts, however you can fulfill contracts and complete objectives to gain new parts and money. There is another mode without the currency system, and then there is the original sandbox mode where anything goes, everything is free.Other than that the game is mostly self-driven. For me, it's the challenge of the game. When I started, landing on the moon was about as far away as, well, the moon. Now I usually spend my time making orbital stations or interplanetary landers using the plethora of mods available (my favorites including b9, remotetech 2, and KAS).The game is almost like a puzzle, if you will; a very, very open-ended puzzle. Massive, towering rockets that take your brave kerbals to the outer reaching planets can perform the same as tiny, lightweight and efficient rockets with a small probe. If I had to rate it, I would definitely give it a 10/10 for the experience it's given me thus far; and so far I haven't lost interest.

content:
Posted: August 11, 2013
Early Access Review
								10/10Kerbal Space Program just might be the game of my life! For someone who is passionate about space exploration, there is simply nothing that even comes close. An enormous sandbox in which you can plan and design your own missions. However ambitious you're feeling, you can think of a mission that will REALLY challenge you. And when you finally reach the goal you had set for yourself, you will feel a tremendous sense of pride and accomplishment. This game can be exquisitely complex, which definitely makes it a niche title - but it's really what makes it so good. My biggest mission to date took me 16 hours, of which roughly 10 were spent designing my gigantic rocket. I like to use real formulae for thrust to weight, planetary transfers, terminal velocity, etc. and plan the entire mission before leaving ground, and not use auto-pilot (mechjeb is what most people use and it can be incredibly helpful). I'm a masochist like that. This game is so good that I try not to play, or else I cannot stop and will not go to bed ever.Even in early access, this game has everything it needs. Make sure you google and search through the numerous mods, which can increase realism and add many features (comm networks, planetary scanning, mining operations, GPS, telescopes, enhanced aerodynamics, to name just a few).Simply incredible.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 16, 2014
Early Access Review
								I think i'll begin this review of Kerbal Space Program with a few stories of things I have done in the game.  First is the quest I had to assemble a modular outpost on the Mun.  Complete with living quarters a solar array/battery bank.  It also had O2 and CO2 storage and a converter.  Finally I added the Kethane(Methane) drilling rig and a plant to convert it to usable rocket fuel.   Next up was the journey to research science from near sun.  I flew a space probe to various altitudes near the sun.  Starting at 1 million km, next 100km, and finally 10,000m.  The last altitude I discovered a fun glitch in the game where the suns gravity accelerated my probe to near the speed of light and it shortly disintegrated.At its core Kerbal Space Program (KSP) is a physics simulation of a solar system and the player is given pieces to make rockets and explore the stars.  Of course there is sandbox mode where all parts are available and the player doesn't have to worry about money or unlocking more advanced parts.  In sandbox the only objective are ones the player must create.  But the real fun starts in career mode that was recently updated to give the player contracts to give them various objectives.  Also part of career mode is the need to balance money and reputation.  The way to unlock better and more advanced parts in career is by performing science.  Of course you might be leary of KSP being early access, but I will say that in terms of content the game is amazing.  I'd buy it in its current state ten times over.  However if you're still not satisfied one of the games biggest strengths is the dedicated modding community.  Want to only focus on building ships and let the autopilot launch and land your crafts.  Theres a mod for that.  Want to add even more rocket parts, the ability to build and connect space crafts.  Theres a mod for that.  Want to make the game super realistic and add O2, CO2, and a realistic atmosphere where your ship can and will burn up during re-entry.  Or you could add Kethane, the games equivalent to Methane, that you can mine and make rocket fuel on distant planets.  Well you see where this is going :)Finally my criticisms.  The biggest one that I hope gets worked on by the devs is optimization.  The physics engine only utilizes a single core of your CPU.  This is frustrating because I have an AMD CPU and not only does it struggle with single core vs Intel but the game doesn't take advantage of my multi core CPU.  Remember that sweet moon station I mentioned, well it got too big and the game ran at ~11 FPS near my station.  Secondly if you install a bunch of mods the games takes a while to load.  Overall if you love Lego and space exploration KSP is an amazing game.

content:
Posted: December 16, 2013
Early Access Review
								Kerbal Space Program a game where you stuff little kerbals into a poorly designed space ship and see what happens. If you strip this game down to the bare min it is a space simulator. But if you add all the different features included with this it makes the game really fun and exciting. What I find about ksp which makes it so great is that it makes hard complicated science of knowing how a ship is built and what to do when its moving into small bitesized peices so that it doesn't overwhelm the player and just make the game not fun. For me I found this game really fun to play with all the features it has because I enjoy science after few hours of playing I found myself learning how orbits work and how a spaceships work. I find any simulator I play I end up wanting to know more about it. If a campaign added makes the game even more fun to play. The game brings a lot of expermenting and doesn't just tell the player everything which adds to the enjoyment of sending kerbals into rockets and letting them go flying. I would defintly recommend this game it would be my best buy really fun and enjoyable to play even due it is £19.99 i got every penny out of it. I would rate this 9/10 lets you be a rocket scienceist with knowing to much.

content:
Posted: January 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is amazing and if you are thinking about buying it, you should. It is still in development and the developers are adding many new features in 2014, among them are big ticket features such as multiplayer are planned. The community is very helpful and there is a large proportion of mods and tutorials available online. If you enjoy sandbox oriented games, do not look far, for this game has both sandbox and objective oriented modes. Bugs do happen, but are not as frequent and disastrous as one might expect, and often go unnoticed. Kerbal Space Program is well rounded, often humorous, and overall fun and easily enjoyable. I myself took almost a solid 10 hours getting to the Mün, and while it was extremely painful to watch myself fail time and time again, it was enjoyable to just build vehicles bound only by physics.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 15, 2013
Early Access Review
								Kerbal Space Program is one of my "Games of the Generation" for whatever that may be worth (the other one is a certain game with Souls that are Dark...you know.)I will skip what KSP is, to make it short, a Space Program Simulator. You build Spacecraft like Rockets, Landers and Rovers and try to get them to other celestial bodies in the simulation...or you can mess around with your creations and create huge deadly fireworks, that works too ;)What makes KSP so special to me is the sense of achievement it conveys when you finally get something right. Let me make this clear right away, KSP is not a simple or easy game. Your first hours will consist of hillarious failiure (if you don´t consult any guides). But once you get your first stable orbit, it feels like you really achieved something, which you did, getting a functional spacecraft in orbit is NOT easy for a beginner. And it only gets more complex AND awesome from there. In Sandbox-Mode, you have no goals beside the ones you set for yourself. Want to go to the furthes planet and set up a network of probes there? You can do it...if you can do it ;)KSP consists of two main modes while you play: Building your vessels and then launching and controlling them. The cool thing is, KSP is not only fun, it also teaches you some things about Astrophysics, even if the physics here are simplified.Bottom Line:If you like thinkey, slowpaced games that let you build and lead your creations to success, if you AT ALL like Space and the wonderful endeavour that is traveling to other celestial bodies, careful maneauvering and putting your very own flag down on the moon (you can totally do that btw), you HAVE to play Kerbal Space Program, one of the most ambitious, brave and rewarding games about space you will ever play.One final word about Early Access: KSP is in development, yes, but it already offers SO much content and possibilites, let alone Mods for just about anything, that I can see no reason not to jump on the KSP-train right now. The sooner you get it, the sooner you will feel that satisfaction when the blue sky fades, the stars shining brightly above your small vessel while the sound of your rocket slowly gets quieter, only to be replaced by the serene soundtrack and a feeling of awe when you´re confronted with space....you can probably tell how much I like this game ;)

								If you're thinking about buying this game if you have not purchased it yet... Let me give you a few reasons why it is worth getting. content:

Early Access Review
								Bloody great game!at the beginning it seems inceredible hard to to even do something as simple as bringing a capsule into orbit or performing the docking of two vessels (Youtube helps).once u understand the simple orbital mechanics it starts getting really cool.u ever wanted to have ur own MÜNBASE? just build it.u ever wanted to do research on other planets? just get there.its all about orbital logistics and proper kerbal engineering.fiddeling rockets for a specialzed task together and optimizing them is a lot of fun.and when it works u really get the feeling u achieved something.and there is a damn crapton of really good mods (Kerbal Spaceport is the official Mod Site). from simple part packs, over complete solar system rescaling to the real size of our solar system, over warpdrive plugins to resource harvesting mods .building a münbase to harvest fuel to refill ur vessel which is supposed to reach the outer planets?get the mod and do it.(all mods are easy to install and remove)but enough about the mods even the normal game got a lot of really cool things to discover.even tho that the game has by now "ONLY" the half of the promised features (things like the finised career mode or multi player), the damn game still better than quite some AAA titles which charge u 50 bucks and hand u a unfinished and unplayble game (X rebirth *cough*)if u thinking about getting ur hands on this game ...... DO IT !

content:
Posted: January 15, 2014
Early Access Review
								I never knew flying out into space in a cardboard box could be so tranquil and beautiful.This is probably my favorite game on Steam; I have had it for a little while now (since about v0.14).  I have put many hours into KSP and yet I still don't know how to describe the character and depth this game has to offer.  It is perfectly situated in that place where silliness and fiction meet complex science and math to form a uniquely fantastic game.  The creative graphics, gameplay and interface are very well in tune with each other and work in tandem quite effectively. The community add-ons greatly enhance the experience and are a must-have for those who like to spice up their missions.  The mod base is so extensive, you can incorporate everything from epic science modules and probe paraphernalia to loads of different rocket engines, solar panels, and landing gear.Most importantly however, you can in fact launch a kerbal into orbit, deorbit him, and watch him burn up in the atmosphere until he hits the ground at 120 meters per second.  Of course, if he lands head-first, it is interesting to watch as his indestructible helmet propels him several hundred meters back into the air.Overall, I believe that KSP is for gamers of all types and can be suited very easily to the user.  I can live with the cons because they're all either bound to be fixed or don't even matter anyways.  I always keep coming back for more kerbal adventures.Solid 100/10 because it makes me chuckle

content:
Posted: April 27, 2015
Early Access Review
								Space; the final frontier. We might not be able to explore our solar system, launch countless space stations and monsterous rockets in real life, but virtually anything is possible in Kerbal Space Program. This is ultimately how an early access game should be done, and I'm writing this on the launch day of 1.0 as it's coming out of Beta. It's come a long way with a massive community of modders out there, which thankfully are not going to turn into paid mods--and developers who listen to, as well as have hired members of the community to help with the game. It can be relentless, it can be fun, and at times hilarious. Whether you're an absolute beginner, have some rudimentary knowledge of rocketry--this can be great for people of all playing styles and ages. You also don't have to dedicate a whole lot of time--jump in for 5 minutes, or a few hours. Want to just blow up rockets? That's fine. Space Station nut with no goal of exploration? You're missing out, but that's fine too. Are you like me and love building entire networks of probes and satellites? Ah, that's fun and quite the challenge. The experience is quite something unique, and I can't recommend this enough. Pick it up as soon as you can.

But finally, I was able to work up enough means to get quite a few games, KSP at the top of the list. The game is amazing, I'll list my Pro's and Con's below (cons being low)Pros:Vast universe with amazing details.Great physicsUpdates aren't cheesy!Funny little green guysSo much to do, new things to craftExtremely addictiveCons:No multiplayer (yet)Not enough green guysFor some reason when you multiply speed whilst lifting, u go boom.All in all, this game is amazing, and you should so totally get it9.9/10

content:
Posted: March 30, 2015
Early Access Review
 Pros Absolutely Beautiful: The visuals in this game, even unmodded, are stunning. I particularly enjoy flying a ship into orbit around the Mun, going into cockpit view and watching Kerbin rise over the horizon.Something should also be said about the seemlessness of transitions between the surface of planets and the solar system at large. With zero loading screens, you can go from the surface of a planet, to orbit, to an inter-planetary flight, to another orbit, to the surface of another planet. This is, frankly, pretty amazing.Challenging: The feeling of finally being able to step out onto the surface of the Mun, after hours of failed attempts at getting into orbit, after countless revisions in rocket designs... Words fail me. But it gets exponentially better with each milestone you pass.The new campaign mode adds a lot to the challenge level as well. Having limits set on the amount of weight you can launch, having to balance the cost of your flights against your program's budget. It definitely adds a new dimension to the game that's a lot of fun. Cons The campaign mode, at least the last time I played, is somewhat lacking in content. Also, there isn't much to do on other planets. There are missions to set up extra-planetary bases and so forth, but once you have them up there, they don't really do much.  Conclusion While the game is still in early access, what they have so far is amazing, and almost worth the price all on its own. I'm really looking forward to further updates.

content:

												This is one of the very few games that will make me laugh like an idiot. One time was when I decided to simply stick a bunch of parchutes on the jet plane I built because I suck at landing. I laughed my♥♥♥♥♥off because my silly idea actually worked beautifully, I laughed as I watched the plane drift gently down to the ground. Then there's Jebediah... He's always so damn happy, even if the rocket is exploding around him. :DI love how this game actually has a quite realistic and sophisticated physics simulator but at the same time you can build some truly insane rockets. This is a unique game, I have never played anything like it, and I keep coming back to it, because it always makes me laugh. It doesn't just make me laugh though, I find it very satisfying when my overengineered space craft finally makes into orbit and beyond.If you're looking for a unique game that's guaranteed to make you laugh like an idiot, then you should definitely give this game a try.

content:
Posted: May 15, 2013
												Kerbal Space Program is a game about space. If you're interesting in nothing past CoD of Duty: Goats, then stop reading now.---KSP is complex and realistic (mostly) space travel with a twist: it's clear. So instead of being a sleep-deprivied, coffee-addict flight controller who needs to recite more instructions than should logically be in existance, you are simply given the controls the fly the rocket - WASD, camera, throttle, and so on. There is no clutter.KSP has a lot of freedom in what to do in it. Recently, the Campaign mode was introduced, which tasks you with balancing the reputation, budget, and science developments of the Kerbal Space Program whilst pushing further and further and building up to greater things. If you prefer the simpler things, there is also the Science mode, in which the only restriction is having to unlock all the parts, or the Sandbox, where everything is given with no limitations.The main protagonists in the game are the Kerbals. Assuming you are fine with the prospect of cartoonish, green, panicking astronauts screaming as your rocket flies into mountains at Mach 5, KSP's light-hearted side appeals to everyone. Your little kerbals will grin like children at a Minecraft Convention as they gracefully land on the Mun, or enjoy the views of a gas giant and it's moons. Upon landing, you can plop down a flag and claim this ball of regolith for you: because in KSP, the solar system is yours.KSP has many opportunities. You may endeavour on projects from a reusable shuttle, to a space station, to a moon base. If you have the time and ideas to make something, possibilities await. Assisting this is the diversity of the modding community: it is very large and it should even be noted that many ideas have been incorporated by the devs into the game - like the C7 Aerospace parts, whose creator was hired for the staff to help develop them, and the soon-to-be multiplayer function: something that was off-limits for the staff before, until it was proven by a modification that multiplayer and KSP can indeed go together.The Official KSP forums have areas for user built craft and items, help and assistance, and pictures and discussion. It's worth a visit if you have any questions, need a helping hand, or simply wish to browse the latest craft available.If you're interested by KSP at this point, don't hesitate to consider buying. It's an excellent game and will continue to improve - because it's still in development.

								Do you like rockets? Do you like explosions? Do you like silly green men? Never fear, all are found within!In Kerbal Space Program (KSP), you build rockets and toss them into outer space. Hopefully. Sometimes they explode, sometimes they land in the water a few thousand kilometers away because you were 10 m/s short on your delta-V.Once you get the hang of it, you can make rockets, space planes, trips to the Mun or other planets, or maybe even crash something into the sun if you're feeling the need for a good tan.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 24, 2016
												Kerbal Space Program is my absolute favourite game.This game probably won't teach you enough to land a job at NASA, but you will get a better grasp on a wide range of aerospace topics than you will by browsing wikipedia for hours.This game has had it's fair share of controversy in it's development process and may not be updated for a long time. But the game in it's current state is easily good enough for another 200 hours. With a great community and more mods than your average bogan's car, you will always find a mod that can change the way you play. I currently have 52 different mods installed that focus on things from procedural aeroplane and rocket parts to hundreds of different varieties of explosive ordnance.In closing, this game will teach you in-depth space flight mechanics, will give you hundreds of hours of fun and will keep you wildly entertained with it's great community and mod support.10/10 Couldn't recommend more(P.S. Use CKAN for easy mod installation)

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								Best Game Ever!.. In my opinion anyway ;)If you have a background of interest in sandbox and/or simulator games you're sure to get your money's worth of enjoyment out of Kerbal Space Program.The game is renowned for having a truly Everest like learning curve. So if you're a type to be frustrated when things don't work first time round beware.However, at this point the game has a nice set of tutorials to get you going on the basics and some clearly thought out scenarios which you can use to drop you in situations to practice most other things (without going to the trouble of getting those pesky rockets off the launch pad).I have found the game to be relatively low on bugs at this point (although rockets do have a tendency to fall apart on the launch pad sometimes). But as the game is still early access it's safe to assume these will be fixed with time.Overall Kerbal is a Great Game. Lots of depth for those willing to put in the time and the promise of comical failures and explosions for all!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								Fantastic game to burn time on, the constant requirement of science points runs as an incentive to carry on building spacecraft and attempting to land/orbit different worlds. I heard about this game from my friends and was reluctant to get it at first as I didn't know if I would enjoy it, or get a lot out of it. As soon as I got it in the sale I knew that I would definitely pay full price for it. Some better tutorials can be found on YouTube so have a look there if you're stuck. Personally I love this game, it keeps me hooked in whenever I start to play it, getting into the orbit of different celestial bodies is always a challenge and landing on them even more so. Also having to consider the levels of fuel, your craft weight, drag and many other elements are just features of this game that make it successful. I've had moments where I've thought, "I fancy going on KSP for a couple of minutes" a couple hours later I'm soaring around the solar system attempting to collect as many science points as possible before I return to Kerbin. Seriously a fantastic game whether you want to play it genuinely or just want to burn a bit of time. I highly recommend this and if you're into your space stuff then this is the perfect game.I rate it a good 9/10.

content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
Early Access Review
								Definitely one of the top 10 games in 2013. This game blew up once it hit YouTube and Steam. Just like Minecraft, it got it's success from other people talking and sharing about it. In this game you get to make spaceships and fly them to different planets and moons. This game has a lot of modding capabilities to it, so it allows you to add, take out, or edit almost anything in the game; like items and bodies in the solar system. At default, the game has set bodies in the solar system which are about 10 times less distant in game as they are in real life (but don't take this as a negative, it is perfect like this). If you want a real challenge, people have made a mod to correct the distances of planets. Modding capabilities in this game are infinite. This game allows anyone to become the astronaut they always wanted to be. I would highly recommend buying this game.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 17, 2013
Early Access Review
								Kerbal Space Program is the ultimate game of exploration, but once you get beneath the suface it is so much more than that. You are your own space program.  Dream it, build it, fly it for better or for worse. You will find yourself wanting to learn the complexities of orbital mechanics. You will find yourself designing larger and more complex things. You will never forget that first time you land on The Mun and live. Then you will discover it's wonderful community. The devs that listen and interact with it. You will find yourself waiting anxiously for each and every patch with glee knowing that this is still the early days. It is well on it's way to being one of the greatest games ever made and just continues to get better. This will be the 'it' game in due time and in this time of games becoming dumber it is nice to play a game that decides to be complex and  difficult. It will capture your imagination, test your mind and allow you to fulfill all of those childhood dreams of reaching for the stars. Get this game and shoot for the heavens. You won't regret it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 6, 2013
Early Access Review
								This is my favorite  steam game that I own. It is really cool designing your own Rockets and Planes, flying to other planets, docking on your space station and adding new scientific tools or even simply going around the moon on a rover. I would definitely recommend this game as it combines science with fun. This game is extremely realistic in almost all the areas including orbit mechanics and other areas like aerodynamic drag. Some parts are unrealistic like there is no re-entry heat in the regular game but if you go to KerbalSpacePort.com which is created by Kerbal Space Program, you can get many mods which add alot to the game. If you wanted to simulate re-entry, get the deadly re-entry mod and be sure to put Heat Shields on your space ship. If you want more plane parts, get B9 Aerospace. For more rocket parts, I recommend KW Rocketry. You can find a mod for almost everything from new parts to new things you can do like creating a map of the planets with a satellite and then using it to find a cool place to land. This game gets a 5/5 rating from me and since it is only in Beta, I expect more to come since already, this looks like an official game. ~Mountain Lion~

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
Early Access Review
								Very fun game!Highly original and addictive.Game PlayVery original. This game is very interesting as it fells like a simulator, but plays like a game.The game is very flexible and you can do just about anything! This game is also great if you are in any way interesting in physics, space exploration and of course rocket science.*Note: The game's physics aren't perfectly accurate as they only take into account one body at a timeGraphicsthis game looks very nice! The planets and effects look good and the parts have a fair amount of detail (though I wish they we a bit higher res). Though the game can be hard to run (see next part).Performance and DevelopmentThe game is in Early Access so it's for ever changing. As of when this review was made the game is only 32 bit (A full 64 bit version is in the works but is quite buggy). If you don't know what that meant here is an explanation (www.techsupportalert.com/content/32-bit-and-64-bit-explained.htm) The game's campaign is just starting to be implemented (with the new science system) and if the game doesn't have what you want check the modding scene.ModdingThis game is very mod friendly. Though it doesn't have an API it has a official modding website (with improvements in the works). The modding community is very active with LOTS of new parts and better aerodynamics and more game play.If this game looks interesting to you in any way I would say it's worth your money!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game, Is one of my favorites games of all time, I played since september 2012, the gameplay mechanics of this game, are like no other game I have seen before, Its idea of going to space, Landing in other celestial bodies, building a base, creating a space station, doing science, doing orbital mechanics, crashing with things and planets, messing around, experimenting and looking what happens when you do an action or a different thing because you are curious ( because that is an animal instinct), that type of things, that type of things you find in a sanbox, are quite unique... mabye they represent you in a way you express yourself. "Sandbox in space: floating around, and crashing around"  -The game's art-style is quite good, the "Kerbals" and their "quite advanced spacecrafts".-The sound is not something to hate, The music is from royalty free, so it isnt unique.-The graphics arent next-gen, they run very well at unity, they're well done-The controls arent to complicated , I mean they are simple, they arent like flight simulator X.The concept is simple, but the gameplay is sort of complex if you are a newbie, the game itself is somewhat hardcore mostly if you are a casual gamer, or you add mods that complicate your life. This games isnt for everybody and you might♥♥♥♥♥♥off.first I got to say, this game is still in alpha and paying 30 dollars might not be worth it, but it might be, it depends on you, if you are a person who is curious and you love space and little bit of physics, I highly recomend this game, if you are a preson who dosent like space, and dosent like physics and any stuff like that, I recomend you this game, THIS Game even if you buy it and you find it wasnt worth it , It was worth it because this game is like no other and a new experience is always worth it. If you cant afford this game, I still recomend it to you, you can play the demo or download it pirate, BUT having this game and helping the developers is ALWAYS GOOD.My final verdict of this game, Its    94/100 Even if it hasn't an orignal music ( except of one), Its idea complements Mostly everything, this innovation is unique.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 17, 2014
Early Access Review
								The Game's only just officially been released in Beta, but had it never been updated again I could have played it as a finished game (though somewhat lacking in terrain details, i.e. trees etc).KSP is hard, I found it quite a steep learning curve from the usual games I play. Getting to grip's with correct weight distribution, centre of lift and mass, trajectory etc. Its all new to me coming from games such as Eve Online, War Thunder or generic FPS's. But given some time, you soon get to grips with the game, more through trail and error in my case, and it really shines.Some people are incredible at designing and building enormous craft, creative designs, technical and brilliant, and can, using mods, even colonise other planets and celestial bodies in the game. I myself, have successfully landed on Mun just the once and returned (on my first try luckily!), and that's about the best i've managed! KSP's modding community really is incredible, and KSP's developers have invested time looking into the more popular mods for the game and have even incorporated them into the newer releases! They have applauded the inginuety of the community and have taken on all constructive criticism, and have really built an incredible game.I can whole heartedly recommend this game, for the more serious sim gamer, or for those wanting a bit of fun building a rocket and blowing little Kerbels up. If you're creative you will love KSP, just make sure you have a decent CPU if you want to build anything too crazy!This game is still (technically only just) in Beta, but already feels like a finished game, and although I got it a incredibly reduced price in a Humble Bundle package, I would pay the market price, and even more, still knowing it's in Beta.10 Jebs out of 10.

content:
Posted: March 10, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is one of the games that you will either love or hate depending on the one who plays it. There is no action here, no twisted plot, no wepons. Different games exploit different human drives. I guess this one exploits you drive of curiosity and learing. Its about exploration and tinkering, experimenting and laughing about the results. And allthough I am not that fond of games without clear purpose at the end, this one makes me come back. Its fun and that's more than enough for me. How about a 3 stage rocket with a Kerbin as a last stage(and then watch how he reenters the athmosphere)? Can you make a Rocket with 6 solid fuel boosters in series fly? Can you reach the Mun? If you find those questions intriguing, then buy it, it will be worth you while.

content:
Posted: March 27, 2013
Early Access Review
								This easily one of the best games ive ever played.  It is still in early access on steam and ive been playing it since even before it was that, when it was only available through the developers website.I havent played enough of the career mode yet to really comment on it, but the sandbox mode is where the game really shines.  You build epic spaceships from scratch and then launch them, they will almost certainly explode, and so you modify it and try again.  This constant redesigning and retrying feels normal, you dont feel like you are losing or are rubbish at the game, you feel that you can get it to work with just one more try, then eventually you get into space, then into orbit, then to a moon or another planet and the satisfaction never really goes away, you just want to keep going further.I cannot recommend this game enough, if you like space games or simulation games, or even just time waster games then this is the game for you.

Yes the development has had it's teething problems, but the developers have continued to support this game beyond even my own expectations.If you are interesed in space exploration at all, Kerbal Space Program is a must-have game.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								It's obvious from the popping-up of my friends' list that lots of people are playing Kerbal Space Program.  Never-the-less, I avoided it until recently because the little green Kerbals made the game appear to be a whimsical and smirking jaunt more appropriate for a fan of 'The Sims' (oh look my guy is peeing on the floor! Haha!) than for the hardened gamer whose enjoyment of games is based mostly on his level of personal annihilation while playng, like myself.Two days later, when the tail of my robe gets caught in the castor of my computer chair, I curse and tug on it a couple of times, but decide to leave it because my launch window is about to close.  Burn!  Full prograde burn!  I'm frantically watching my liquid fuel deplete and trying to stay on target as I burn for home, my onboard computer full of data I collected from my first successful landing on Duna.  I can already imagine what technologies I might unlock with the trove of scientific knowledge I've picked up on this flight.  I collected temperature and barometric pressure readings at several altitudes in Duna's thin atmosphere, I collected surface samples from two different substrates, I have a pod full of goo reacting strangely to the radiation in space, damnit I have to get home!  My robe is still caught in the wheel and the cat is eating his food out of the can.  Anhillation level: high.Is Kerbal Space Program a whimsical jaunt?  Yes, but is also a deep and involving sim where you are creating the story of your space program as you play.  I recently landed on the Mun (the moon) and recued a marooned Kerbal who'd crash landed there on one of my earliest missions.  I planted a flag saying "Bob Kerman was here 636 days escaped to space.  Tell Kelly Frears, Memphis TN I love her."  I've fretted over what technologies to unlock and had a blast piecing together launch vehicles and watched in horror as they broke apart during staging before breaking atmo, pounded my desk in triumph as my lander touched down after dropping my first rover on the Mun.  Career mode is the only mode I have played, collecting science and earning money completing contracts, e.g. testing a new parachute high in the atmosphere for the manufacturer, but if you are more of a creative tinkerer who needs to be unhinged, other game modes exist where you don't need to manage cash or unlock tech.  I highly recommend this game in its current state of pre-release 0.25 (i think).  It is already more of a game than most finished products.  Evey feature implemented works and adds to the experience, nothing is broken and there is loads more on the way.  I'll try to get my robe untangled by the time they release multiplayer.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
Early Access Review
								Mun or bust!  Put those solid fuel boosters on that capsule and send mastermind Jebediah Kerman on a trip to.. whatever it is you hit in space!In Kerbal Space Program you're put in charge of a Space Center run by Kerbals, the inhabitants of Kerbin, a race so eager to explore space they'd put rockets on everything.Your job is to build Rockets, Rovers, Space-Planes.. yes, even Space Stations and launch them into Space to explore/ fly-around-in and land (or crash) into and onto Moons, Planets and even Asteroids and build your scientific base there.There's really only one downside, and that's an incredibly steep learning curve. Thanks to an incredible amount of Video and Written Tutorials on the Web, especially Youtube, you're get a hang of it in due time. The game also comes with a few basic tutorials on how to build a ship and maneuvering it in space.It takes a bit of scientific knowledge to understand how moving in space works. Kerbal Space Program (KSP) often refers to scientific terms for things and is proud of itself as being a very realistic presentation of how Space works.If you can get past your early crashes and misbuilt ships, what lies ahead of you is a journey to the stars with your own crew of Kerbals, in your very own Ship towards a Planet you're going to put your flag on.The Game offers a Campaign and a Sandbox mode. In Sandbox you can pretty much do whatever the heck you want. Build a Ship out of infinite materials and try launching it into space, or better, try landing it somewhere. In the Carreer Mode of the Game you need to start with baby steps. Perform some easy things like orbiting, collecting Scientific Data along the way and hiring new Astronauts to help you in your quest for the Stars and gaining new Materials. Slowly explore Space and the many things it has to offer.With lots of user created mods and community created overhauls for Sounds and Textures and a generally booming Modding Community that is also being appreciated and even incorporated into the Games releases you'll never run out of new Materials for building your dream-ship.Now go and conquer those Stars.4.5/5

content:
Posted: December 6, 2013
Early Access Review
								This is my favorite  steam game that I own. It is really cool designing your own Rockets and Planes, flying to other planets, docking on your space station and adding new scientific tools or even simply going around the moon on a rover. I would definitely recommend this game as it combines science with fun. This game is extremely realistic in almost all the areas including orbit mechanics and other areas like aerodynamic drag. Some parts are unrealistic like there is no re-entry heat in the regular game but if you go to KerbalSpacePort.com which is created by Kerbal Space Program, you can get many mods which add alot to the game. If you wanted to simulate re-entry, get the deadly re-entry mod and be sure to put Heat Shields on your space ship. If you want more plane parts, get B9 Aerospace. For more rocket parts, I recommend KW Rocketry. You can find a mod for almost everything from new parts to new things you can do like creating a map of the planets with a satellite and then using it to find a cool place to land. This game gets a 5/5 rating from me and since it is only in Beta, I expect more to come since already, this looks like an official game. ~Mountain Lion~

content:
Posted: December 17, 2013
Early Access Review
								Kerbal Space Program is the ultimate game of exploration, but once you get beneath the suface it is so much more than that. You are your own space program.  Dream it, build it, fly it for better or for worse. You will find yourself wanting to learn the complexities of orbital mechanics. You will find yourself designing larger and more complex things. You will never forget that first time you land on The Mun and live. Then you will discover it's wonderful community. The devs that listen and interact with it. You will find yourself waiting anxiously for each and every patch with glee knowing that this is still the early days. It is well on it's way to being one of the greatest games ever made and just continues to get better. This will be the 'it' game in due time and in this time of games becoming dumber it is nice to play a game that decides to be complex and  difficult. It will capture your imagination, test your mind and allow you to fulfill all of those childhood dreams of reaching for the stars. Get this game and shoot for the heavens. You won't regret it.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 11, 2016
												KSP is a physics game which means its not for everyone. It is somewhat technical but thanks to its cartoonish approach funny at the same time.You build your rocket or your plane in the hangar, go to the launchpad/runway and watch it fly ( or die trying ). The graphics are pretty basic but that has no negative impact on the game for me (i for one prefer a good game to good looks).It can be somewhat repetitive. You're going to repeat ALOT of your flights until they yield the results you set out for but with the tinkering in between trying to optimize your design its okay for me.There are 3 gameplay-modes to choose from. 1) Sandbox: just build what you want and let it fly. 2) Science: Get scientific data from different locations to advance your rockets like various climate zones of your own planet, in flight, in orbit, heck even swimming in the ocean and in space of course. Just worry about the data no matter the costs. 3) Career: You pretty much run the whole show yourself if its science/piloting/managing/work on contracts etc.For me it was totally worth it and im not done yet. :D

content:
Posted: December 22, 2016
												BEST. GAME. EVER. GO SQUAD GO!!!!!!!!!1!!!!!!!!!!!one!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!!! :DWell, apart from the sheer fanboyism, lets get serious, because this game deserves it. I have been playing this since the early builds before getting it on Steam, so i calculate i have well over 3000 hours logged total.  And if you expect flight action, or fancy cutscenes and effects, or a more casual game based on surreal spaceship propulsion systems, this game is not for you. Really. This game requires you to actually use your brain and learn things. It is disguised graphically as a cute little sandbox with them kerbals and fun explosions, but the truth is that this is a realflight rocket, spaceship, plane, and orbital simulator. Which means you will need to LEARN in a relatively DIFFICULT way things like orbital mechanics, manouvers, how to rendezvous and dock ships in orbit manually, and that kind of things. Expect a HIGH learning curve. Which in my humble opinion is worth its weight in diamonds in this world of stupid games we live in, but i digress. The game makes you learn things about space, spaceships, real propulsion systems, aerodinamics, and in general how things are done in real life with rockets and satellites, spaceplanes and such.... really i have no words that make it justice.If your are an all things space aficionado, or always wanted to be, this game is a no brainer great choice for you. Plus Squad are great guys that are always improving the game in giant steps, like the recent comms net and satellite signal system, and you can always expect improvements. And also the communitiy is great, the mod scene is greatly supported... It's all good! Go get it!!My only little grudge with it is that it still has no real habitat and life support simulation, appart from G force or heat exposure, but everything will eventually come, as always  :)

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								The only game I have ever played that, when successfully building and launching a rocket to then deploy a lander on the moon followed by an elaborate docking process once back in space led to an ambitious return to the home planet without killing any of my crewmen, gave me a TRUE sense of personal accomplishment that has rivalled real-life accomplishments. That may sound lame to some of you who are not hardcore about gaming, while it may sound strange to you hardcore gamers who find accomplishment in successes from other games. I tell you this being a 29-year old gamer veteran of 25 long years (Tandy PC jr., TI Home Computer, Amiga, Commodore 64, and Atari 2600 for starters) who has seen many games come and go. I'm sure that Kerbal may not be a true pioneer of the sandbox sim, yet I have never met a game that has kept me riveted to my PC for as long as this one.Kerbal can create an experience never lived for most of you who grew up wanting either to be an astronaut or a rocket scientist (or both!) and presents it in a fashion that is otherwise unattainable in any other media form. The creation process can be frustrating and unforgiving, between the thrust/mass/control coefficients and the staging management ensuring your success/demise right at the paddock, yet always gives a personal sense of enjoyment when your self-concocted combination of (loosely) held together parts engineered for home plumbing/rocketry when it finally does work out and you break that atmospheric threshold between Kerbin and space.The graphics are solid; with a moderate gaming laptop or mediocre desktop PC, this game can still shine. The only time I have run into issues with my Ivy Bridge i7 with 670MX GPU laptop running all features @1080p is when I created a six-part space station with lighting fixtures in low orbit (125 km). This causes some choppy camera effects which can easily be resolved with lowering res or AA.The physics are unmatched; the way each rocket adds mass with thrust, providing an unnerving sense of realism to having too much or not enough on either of these factors. This is a mechanism that other space games should take note of.The story is unnecessary and therefore (so far) omitted. This is an exploration game with no prome directive. If Squad does finalize the game and provide any type of a campaign, it will only be a plus on an already incredible design.The gameplay is certainly something special; you build, launch, stage, deploy, land, and dock to your heart's content! There are also some other great features Squad has done with the R&D facility and science points (it provides a heck of a challenge starting with very little to promote a scientific approach to your exploration and desire for more research). The full solar system exploration will provide countless hours of efforts to send unmanned satellites to the farthest reaches, and perhaps even manned vessels of you are REALLY amibitious. Overall this game, as it stands, is a 10/10 even though there is still so much left for it to improve on but the foundation of what is the single greatest Early Access Game released on Steam certainly surpasses the expectations I could have ever had of it.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
Early Access Review
								This is one of the best games I have ever played.  It is an indie game and not yet in full release, but the developers are highly communicative with the community and regular updates are released almost always adding major features or bug fixes.  The modding community is extremely dedicated and the developers are highly supportive of it to the point where they have hired several of the best modders straight from the community.I've put over 250 hours into this game since its been on Steam, but that doesn't count the hundreds of hours I put in before it was on Steam.The game is extremely worth it and has an extremely bright future ahead of it.  There is no clear objective system at the moment though, which has turned some people off the game.  I don't believe its coming in the next update but their main priority is currently fleshing out the 'career' mode (as opposed to the sandbox mode that most people play) where there will be objectives, funding, and research.  Research has already been added but it needs some major fixing, which is actually their expressed priority for the coming update.TLDR; The game is very much worth it, if you're interested in spacetravel at all go for it.  The satisfaction of landing on the Mun (Kerbal equivalent of the Moon) on your own for the first time more than makes it worth the cost, not to mention the hundreds of other things there are for you to do.Oh, and if you're still on the fence there is a free demo for you to try.  It only includes a fraction of the parts and celestial bodies that are available in the full version and does not include the career mode, but it gives you a good idea of what the full game is like.
