content:
Posted: December 4, 2013
Early Access Review
								Definitely one of the top 10 games in 2013. This game blew up once it hit YouTube and Steam. Just like Minecraft, it got it's success from other people talking and sharing about it. In this game you get to make spaceships and fly them to different planets and moons. This game has a lot of modding capabilities to it, so it allows you to add, take out, or edit almost anything in the game; like items and bodies in the solar system. At default, the game has set bodies in the solar system which are about 10 times less distant in game as they are in real life (but don't take this as a negative, it is perfect like this). If you want a real challenge, people have made a mod to correct the distances of planets. Modding capabilities in this game are infinite. This game allows anyone to become the astronaut they always wanted to be. I would highly recommend buying this game.

content:
Posted: July 13, 2014
Early Access Review
								Bought this game on a Saturday night after watching some youtube videos about it. By Sunday night I had sunk 15 hours into it and landed Jebediah on Minmus and brought him back with fumes to spare in the tank.This is a very much playable game as is, and Squad (devs) are planning on adding more to it to make it even better. Well worth the money in my opinion.This is a highly detailed game. Yes, you will start of very basic with rockets, but it quickly scales up so that you need to plan stability, lift, mass, etc, before you even hit the launch pad. Youtube will be your friend trying to learn decent builds to get you started, but once you get the basics, the fun is in the experimentation, trying to find what works best for you.I have only begun to scratch the surface, but I am looking forward to spending many hours trying out different builds, different tactics, and try to plant my flag on the surface of any and all planets that I can.

content:
Posted: August 11, 2014
Early Access Review
Abosultly amazing! There is so much I love about KSP, The Kerbals themselves are funny, theres the learning, I've learned so much about physics, essentially rocket science, also atmospheric flight dynamics(you can also make and fly planes in KSP to, although for me its harder than the rocket science), There comes a great sense of acomplishment when you finally get it right, It is a very challenging game, it really works my brain, to think outside of the box, to be innovative to get the craft to get the job done. There's a great community with this game, here on steam, but my favorite places for all things KSP is reddit /r/kerbalspaceprogram and also KSP offical forums. Theres also Fantastic people like Scott Manley on YouTube, to help you get started with Your Space program. (I still refer to his videos all the time.)KSP does have a STEEP Learning curve, but its worth it.I bought it on sale, but knowing what I do now, I would pay full price, I would pay even more for it.And then theres the mods, which can make the game even better.For a beginning player I would recommend starting out with some of the tutorials(theres more now than when I started), and then experimenting in sandbox mode, then if you feel so inclined jump into career mode, theres where the real challenge lies.I may have other games with more logged hours, but this is probally my favorite game I own.I Love KSP!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								For an early access game this gem is already quite playable and thoroughly enjoyable.  With the recent addition of the Asteroid Redirect Mission update patch, which was designed in cooperation with NASA, Squad has taken the game to new heights.  It really is hard to believe that so much more is still to come and this is only early access.   Kerbal Space Program already has a great community base, excellent rapport with the developers and an huge community of modders as well as a large number of demos, play-alongs and tutorials available in video on the web. Don't hesitate!  This game is already great and just gets better with each new feature as the game develops.  Explore the Kerbin system with all the part available in sandbox mode or start off with just the basics in career mode and do science missions to research more and better parts as you explore outward from Kerbin to the other planets around the sun, Kerbol.  Watch your Kerbalnauts grin in joy and excitement or scream in adject terror as you launch them into space.  There is no other game quite like Kerbal Space Program.

Early Access Review
								If you like space, rockets, and endangering the lives of little green astronauts, welcome to Kerbal Space Program! This game offers building your own rockets, assembling space stations, shooting satellites into orbit, landing rovers on celestial bodies, and doing all other sorts of SCIENCE! KSP is all about trial-and-error, so you'll need a lot of patience for your many attempts to get anything functional into orbit, but if you have the patience and love anything space-related, this game will not disappoint a bit. With near-endless replayability, constant updates, and beautiful mod support, KSP is the game that keeps on giving.

content:
Posted: May 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								I'm not sure what I would say to convince anyone to want to play this game, because it seems to me that you either hear about KSP or watch a video and immediately want to play it, or you do those things and it does not interest you. This is very much a simulator for realistic Newtonian physics and orbital mechanics, with some cute frumpy alien creatures goggling in wonder at the universe thrown in to make you smile.I've played a whole lot of this game. Several orders of magnitude more than it would appear from my profile because I originally purchased the non-steam version (for easier Linux support). I recently purchased a second steam copy, if that says anything about the game. I've played it on all three supported platforms and it works perfectly, even under Slackware Linux. From that I assume it's very distro agnostic.When I started out with the game, the only mode was the Sandbox mode. This can be a little overwhelming to the uninitiated due to the sheer volume of parts to play with. Since then the Career mode has been added, which limits the parts that you can use and requires you to run missions and gain science to research new parts. This allows you to slowly gain an understanding of all of the parts, and is something that really enhanced my enjoyment of the game.In the end, you get out of the game what you're willing to put into it. Even in the career mode, the only objective you have is "gain science", so it's up to you to conceive of missions that take you to new places to do that. The game is very much not a guided experience.Do note however that there are a few short training missions that give you the basics of how to build rockets and fly them. What you do with that knowledge is up to you.

content:
Posted: May 15, 2013
												Kerbal Space Program is a game about space. If you're interesting in nothing past CoD of Duty: Goats, then stop reading now.---KSP is complex and realistic (mostly) space travel with a twist: it's clear. So instead of being a sleep-deprivied, coffee-addict flight controller who needs to recite more instructions than should logically be in existance, you are simply given the controls the fly the rocket - WASD, camera, throttle, and so on. There is no clutter.KSP has a lot of freedom in what to do in it. Recently, the Campaign mode was introduced, which tasks you with balancing the reputation, budget, and science developments of the Kerbal Space Program whilst pushing further and further and building up to greater things. If you prefer the simpler things, there is also the Science mode, in which the only restriction is having to unlock all the parts, or the Sandbox, where everything is given with no limitations.The main protagonists in the game are the Kerbals. Assuming you are fine with the prospect of cartoonish, green, panicking astronauts screaming as your rocket flies into mountains at Mach 5, KSP's light-hearted side appeals to everyone. Your little kerbals will grin like children at a Minecraft Convention as they gracefully land on the Mun, or enjoy the views of a gas giant and it's moons. Upon landing, you can plop down a flag and claim this ball of regolith for you: because in KSP, the solar system is yours.KSP has many opportunities. You may endeavour on projects from a reusable shuttle, to a space station, to a moon base. If you have the time and ideas to make something, possibilities await. Assisting this is the diversity of the modding community: it is very large and it should even be noted that many ideas have been incorporated by the devs into the game - like the C7 Aerospace parts, whose creator was hired for the staff to help develop them, and the soon-to-be multiplayer function: something that was off-limits for the staff before, until it was proven by a modification that multiplayer and KSP can indeed go together.The Official KSP forums have areas for user built craft and items, help and assistance, and pictures and discussion. It's worth a visit if you have any questions, need a helping hand, or simply wish to browse the latest craft available.If you're interested by KSP at this point, don't hesitate to consider buying. It's an excellent game and will continue to improve - because it's still in development.

Posted: June 19, 2015
												Been playing this game for years now.  It comes close to having endless replayability.  Not to sound cliche but the only real limits are your imagination and your ability to build and fly the contraptions you create.The first time I played this I played for 26 hours straight without really noticing the time going by, this was back when there was only the Mun to visit and maybe 20 something parts to build with.  Building a complex craft can consume an entire day.  Flying it and getting the ship to its destination can take longer.  Not to say this game is tedious, every step of the way you are challenged in multiple ways as you complete your goals.If you like space, if you have any interest in modern and historic spaceflight and aeronautics then you should check this game out.Its graphics while simple are beautiful.  It is often funny, and always challenging.  Its like lego except you get to take your creations outside and fly them to the moon and beyond.So if a game where you can build a large orbital plane carrier then fly it to a distant moon to launch planes into its atmosphere sounds like something you enjoy, you should try this game.

content:
Posted: April 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								For an early access game this gem is already quite playable and thoroughly enjoyable.  With the recent addition of the Asteroid Redirect Mission update patch, which was designed in cooperation with NASA, Squad has taken the game to new heights.  It really is hard to believe that so much more is still to come and this is only early access.   Kerbal Space Program already has a great community base, excellent rapport with the developers and an huge community of modders as well as a large number of demos, play-alongs and tutorials available in video on the web. Don't hesitate!  This game is already great and just gets better with each new feature as the game develops.  Explore the Kerbin system with all the part available in sandbox mode or start off with just the basics in career mode and do science missions to research more and better parts as you explore outward from Kerbin to the other planets around the sun, Kerbol.  Watch your Kerbalnauts grin in joy and excitement or scream in adject terror as you launch them into space.  There is no other game quite like Kerbal Space Program.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
												Imagine, if you will, a space program created by you, driven by you, and fulfilled by you. That's KSP. You throw parts together like a kid with a container full of LEGOs, sometimes with disastrous, sometimes with spectacular, sometimes with wonderful results. Want to see what happens when a plane has its rudder at the nose? You can find out. Want to see what happens when a bunch of hot burning solid rockets are placed right next to liquid fuel tanks? You can find out. Necessity is the mother of invention, and you'll need to be inventive to enjoy the game, but you could find yourself learning some things along the way too. The physics are mostly realistic, scaled down so they're more forgiving of mistakes, but the principles are mostly the same. This doesn't mean the game is hard - it just means the world works by a consistent set of principles. This makes it a lot easier than the "physics" in other games, which cheat and flub their way through physics using a cobbled-up set of exclusions and special cases to try and approximate a realistic engine.Word of advice: If you're new to the game, start off in sandbox mode. The other modes are for when you've already learned how the world works, which you'll do by playing in sandbox for a while. Once sandbox is no longer a challenge for you, then start off a new game in career mode. You'll be a hell of a lot happier this way.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 26, 2014
Early Access Review
								It's obvious from the popping-up of my friends' list that lots of people are playing Kerbal Space Program.  Never-the-less, I avoided it until recently because the little green Kerbals made the game appear to be a whimsical and smirking jaunt more appropriate for a fan of 'The Sims' (oh look my guy is peeing on the floor! Haha!) than for the hardened gamer whose enjoyment of games is based mostly on his level of personal annihilation while playng, like myself.Two days later, when the tail of my robe gets caught in the castor of my computer chair, I curse and tug on it a couple of times, but decide to leave it because my launch window is about to close.  Burn!  Full prograde burn!  I'm frantically watching my liquid fuel deplete and trying to stay on target as I burn for home, my onboard computer full of data I collected from my first successful landing on Duna.  I can already imagine what technologies I might unlock with the trove of scientific knowledge I've picked up on this flight.  I collected temperature and barometric pressure readings at several altitudes in Duna's thin atmosphere, I collected surface samples from two different substrates, I have a pod full of goo reacting strangely to the radiation in space, damnit I have to get home!  My robe is still caught in the wheel and the cat is eating his food out of the can.  Anhillation level: high.Is Kerbal Space Program a whimsical jaunt?  Yes, but is also a deep and involving sim where you are creating the story of your space program as you play.  I recently landed on the Mun (the moon) and recued a marooned Kerbal who'd crash landed there on one of my earliest missions.  I planted a flag saying "Bob Kerman was here 636 days escaped to space.  Tell Kelly Frears, Memphis TN I love her."  I've fretted over what technologies to unlock and had a blast piecing together launch vehicles and watched in horror as they broke apart during staging before breaking atmo, pounded my desk in triumph as my lander touched down after dropping my first rover on the Mun.  Career mode is the only mode I have played, collecting science and earning money completing contracts, e.g. testing a new parachute high in the atmosphere for the manufacturer, but if you are more of a creative tinkerer who needs to be unhinged, other game modes exist where you don't need to manage cash or unlock tech.  I highly recommend this game in its current state of pre-release 0.25 (i think).  It is already more of a game than most finished products.  Evey feature implemented works and adds to the experience, nothing is broken and there is loads more on the way.  I'll try to get my robe untangled by the time they release multiplayer.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
Early Access Review
								Mun or bust!  Put those solid fuel boosters on that capsule and send mastermind Jebediah Kerman on a trip to.. whatever it is you hit in space!In Kerbal Space Program you're put in charge of a Space Center run by Kerbals, the inhabitants of Kerbin, a race so eager to explore space they'd put rockets on everything.Your job is to build Rockets, Rovers, Space-Planes.. yes, even Space Stations and launch them into Space to explore/ fly-around-in and land (or crash) into and onto Moons, Planets and even Asteroids and build your scientific base there.There's really only one downside, and that's an incredibly steep learning curve. Thanks to an incredible amount of Video and Written Tutorials on the Web, especially Youtube, you're get a hang of it in due time. The game also comes with a few basic tutorials on how to build a ship and maneuvering it in space.It takes a bit of scientific knowledge to understand how moving in space works. Kerbal Space Program (KSP) often refers to scientific terms for things and is proud of itself as being a very realistic presentation of how Space works.If you can get past your early crashes and misbuilt ships, what lies ahead of you is a journey to the stars with your own crew of Kerbals, in your very own Ship towards a Planet you're going to put your flag on.The Game offers a Campaign and a Sandbox mode. In Sandbox you can pretty much do whatever the heck you want. Build a Ship out of infinite materials and try launching it into space, or better, try landing it somewhere. In the Carreer Mode of the Game you need to start with baby steps. Perform some easy things like orbiting, collecting Scientific Data along the way and hiring new Astronauts to help you in your quest for the Stars and gaining new Materials. Slowly explore Space and the many things it has to offer.With lots of user created mods and community created overhauls for Sounds and Textures and a generally booming Modding Community that is also being appreciated and even incorporated into the Games releases you'll never run out of new Materials for building your dream-ship.Now go and conquer those Stars.4.5/5

								Kerbal space program could quite possibly be the best game i have ever played. and is ground breaking in its own field. the feeling of achievement when you A) build a working rocket. B) get it into orbit. c) send it to another orbiting body D) land it on that orbiting body E) dock the craft, is awesome. every single moment feels like 100%ing any other game (in the words of kennedy) "not because it is easy, but because it is hard". and failure in this game is devastating, seeing rockets explode during launch or failing to reach orbit. or crashing during a landing is gutting, mainly because you can see it all going wrong over  a course of time, and such you get attached to it all. every aspect of this game is rewarding.this game is in early access admittedly, this may put some of you off, but do not let it be so, this game is as polished and tidy as most AAA releases these day, there are no microtransactions here, you are buying practically a finished game.this is a must own game, and i wish more games were as rewarding and enjoyable as this

content:
Posted: April 21, 2015
												This game. I love it. The list of things you can do in this game is really long, including, but not limited to:-Flying-Orbiting Stuff-Falling from the sky-Redirecting asteroids so they fall on random things-Crashing into planets-Summoning the Kraken-Download mods ( lightspeed drives, female astronauts, and other cool stuff )-Whatever else you can do with a fleet of gigantic 3000 ton rocket ships, hacks, and your imagination.If you know basic logic, how to open a how to video and how to open your computer files, then you can even easily mod your own things ( invincible astronauts, indestructible ship parts, engines that have unheard of amounts of DeltaV, etc... )Plus, if you plan on becoming an engineer, this game is pretty realistic when it comes to orbits, acceleration, velocities, aerobraking, and other cool physics stuff. I swear my IQ jumped the moment I started playing this game.Although there is no real end game, there are missions and senarios you can complete, however, for me, the sense of accomplishment of landing an asteroid on top of a building is enough for me to become addicted.I've been playing for about 1,800 hours and I have rarely ever become bored of it. There is always something new, something bigger you can do than that of what you have just done. For example, you can fly to space, great, time to make an orbit, next, to the moon, eventually, you're sending colonisation missions to Mars (Duna), the moons of Jupiter (Jool) and Pluto (Eeloo). I would even go as far to say it has influenced my carrer choices, before I started to play this game, I wasn't very sure on what to do as a profession, now, I'm locked on aerospace engineer.Anyway, I hope you like this game.*After release edit:Sill awesome game. I recommend a mod pack called "realism overhaul" for all of you realists.

content:
Posted: September 30, 2014
												I would reccomend this game time and time again. It does have a steep learning curve, but stay with it. Everything that goes wrong, is going wrong for a reason.Maybe your ship is pulling hard to the right during launch. something like forgetting to add a fuel line in and the rocket becomes unbalanced as you use fuel in the counter weight compartments. This is one small example. If you stick with it, you'll want to go to the moon sooner or later, and when you finally get your intercept course and come into contact with the Muns gravitation pull. Chances are you'll crash into the moon and explode. Get♥♥♥♥♥♥♥♥off, and walk away.But you'll be thinking, "I can land that" and you will.Not only until you manage to re-enter Kerbons atmosphere will you realize you forgot to parachutes.Again you will be mad, again...you will do better.Somewhat of a rant.An easy 10/10 though. Worth the money.After another 200+ hours in the game I still say buy this game.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
Early Access Review
								Very fun game!Highly original and addictive.Game PlayVery original. This game is very interesting as it fells like a simulator, but plays like a game.The game is very flexible and you can do just about anything! This game is also great if you are in any way interesting in physics, space exploration and of course rocket science.*Note: The game's physics aren't perfectly accurate as they only take into account one body at a timeGraphicsthis game looks very nice! The planets and effects look good and the parts have a fair amount of detail (though I wish they we a bit higher res). Though the game can be hard to run (see next part).Performance and DevelopmentThe game is in Early Access so it's for ever changing. As of when this review was made the game is only 32 bit (A full 64 bit version is in the works but is quite buggy). If you don't know what that meant here is an explanation (www.techsupportalert.com/content/32-bit-and-64-bit-explained.htm) The game's campaign is just starting to be implemented (with the new science system) and if the game doesn't have what you want check the modding scene.ModdingThis game is very mod friendly. Though it doesn't have an API it has a official modding website (with improvements in the works). The modding community is very active with LOTS of new parts and better aerodynamics and more game play.If this game looks interesting to you in any way I would say it's worth your money!

content:
Posted: June 19, 2015
												Been playing this game for years now.  It comes close to having endless replayability.  Not to sound cliche but the only real limits are your imagination and your ability to build and fly the contraptions you create.The first time I played this I played for 26 hours straight without really noticing the time going by, this was back when there was only the Mun to visit and maybe 20 something parts to build with.  Building a complex craft can consume an entire day.  Flying it and getting the ship to its destination can take longer.  Not to say this game is tedious, every step of the way you are challenged in multiple ways as you complete your goals.If you like space, if you have any interest in modern and historic spaceflight and aeronautics then you should check this game out.Its graphics while simple are beautiful.  It is often funny, and always challenging.  Its like lego except you get to take your creations outside and fly them to the moon and beyond.So if a game where you can build a large orbital plane carrier then fly it to a distant moon to launch planes into its atmosphere sounds like something you enjoy, you should try this game.

								This game is great! It really lets you unleash your creativity, and it's quite satisfying to land on a planet/moon. However, there are some bugs here and there, but that's expected from an alpha (now beta and still going strong!) game. Plus, there's a steep learning curve for beginners which may demotivate them from playing and learning. While it may not be complete, it's rather fun once you learn. content:
Posted: December 14, 2014
Early Access Review
								  I've really enjoyed this game for the 600 hours I've played it (That's only the documented time, my modded .zips probably add at least 600 more!) The gameplay elements they have now are great, and were even when only Sandbox existed. With the new .90 update coming out, I see alot to look forwards to. Career/Science Modes' ability to change the difficulty and output of science, cash, reputation, and more, makes the game really easy or difficult depending on how you change the percentages. It's near-impossible at 10% everything, but really easy when you hit like 1000% everything.Overall, I really do recommend this game for anyone wanting to have some fun, or really creative, sicence-oriented people. (Also for those who like explosions, but really, who DOESN'T like explosions!)

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 30, 2016
												When I am writting this review, Steam shows 354 hours in game. However due to DRM free and moding, I already spent 1400+ hours (KSP is DRM free and is modable - so I play from non Steam-connected copy which is of stable version and specified mod mix - that is why). And I am counting.What is this game about? Sending green folk (called Kerbals) to space and to another planets. For science. And having TONS and TONS of fun. Well, in case you like rockets, planes, space and explosions. In whatever order. It is so hard to describe the game I advice you to give a check to youtube - e.g. Scott Manleys channel will give you nice view into what KSP is about.I bought this game back in 1.0.5 (32bit only) only out of boredom and to satisfy my game hoarding habbit. What I buy I do try - so I gave it a quick look before just adding it to my library. I tried to launch a rocket (I was unaware of contracts that time) - the chute deployed instead of expected fireshow. Some testing revealed the problem. I launched Jebediah and landed him back... It was kind of fun... Can I make it to orbit? After couple hours at 3 AM (working day followed) I maintained very odd, but stable orbit. I literally danced at my darkened man cave-corner. For two weeks straight, I slept only 4 hours a day. I designed rockets in my head while driving, or falling asleep, I was making sketches of new projects while waiting for a meeting at work, I was (and I still am) proactively looking for books and documentaries to study or inspire myself. I have a time to play at PC only around 4 hours a day at max, but KSP takes much much more hours per day. In times before KSP, when on toilet, I would check the smartphone for funny gifs to have some giggles. Now, I am all about space exploration...In those two weeks I found out I was wrong all my life about microgravity, orbital manneuvers and ascends of rockets. I was actualy learning stuff and I had great time doing so. Then I found out mods. It was like Christmas. Then a 1.1.x versions came and we received completely new engine, 64bit support. I fel in love with superfriendly community around KSP.And all it took, is lego based rocket building. Behind simple concept of straping a big fuel tank and engine under a crew module lies very complex mechanics of orbital physics. I droped my dream to be an astronaut at age of 5 (bad memory of kindergarden "event" - so I am sure). After more than 20 years later, I am back :)You can be new Elon Musk, or a reincarnator of Neil Armstrong. Or would you rather be Werner von Braun? You can be all of this. You can build rockets, planes, rovers, or any mad creation of yours (Kerbal mixer to mix actual Kerbals). ANd with mods, you can do really anything. Game can be easened (assisting mods), widened (parts mod, more planets) turned realistic (RSS/RO) and much more. Well... long text and no actual review of what this game is. Sigh... Ok, go to youtube, check Kerbal Space Program... Does it seem funny? Give it try. I did and it is best game purchase I ever did. I already can play other games, and not touch KSP for two or three days. But I still play, and I still do enjoy it beyond I ever imagined.10/10

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 28, 2016
												I've been playing KSP for a few weeks at this point and have made it all the way to obriting the Mun.Each successful mission has been an ever more impressive triumph which requires a greater depth of understanding and strategy, in asset allocation, construction, mission planning, and execution.I just went skydiving for the first time today. It was beyond words. Amazingly I followed every step in sequence at exactly the right altitudes without my instructor having to remind me. All while screaming toward the ground at up to 120 miles an hour. My instructor was so impressed that she let me land us at the end of the parachute coast after free fall.After it was over I couldn't shake the feeling that I had just successfully landed on the Mun.No game should be so good that you land from a skydive you feel the same exhileration and pride you do from playing it. A trip to the Mun is way more exciting than "a trip to Pittsburg", and it's worth the hard knocks to figure out how to get there.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												You spent hours building that rover just right. Not too much or too little fuel and propulsion, and the craft is properly reinforced with struts (of course).You spent even more time flying the craft to it's destination. The staging was perfect, the orbits calculated just right.Finally, you spend many nerve-wracking minutes landing the rover. In the end, the descent goes without fail, with just enough fuel.There was some sticky moments, but now you are at your destination. You made it to space today, and now it's time to science. You start driving the rover, celebrating your success...Only to realize the rover is not as balanced as you thought, which causes it to fly up and spin out of control in microgravity and explode into 5 million pieces when it strikes the surface.You realize then you forgot Rule #1: Failure is always an option.11/10 Always good for making you question your own intelligence and self-esteem.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 27, 2016
												This is a truly unique game. This is a truly infuriating game.There's nothing I can say bad about this game because 1: I'd call it about 90% stable (compared to a bethesda game that's about 70%). This alone wouldn't matter. Just cuz the game loads and doesn't crash while you play it doesn't mean it's not bad. But for how much time the average Kerbal will play this game, it's a huge factor (Also, the game takes about 10 minutes to load if you have anywhere near 100 mods installed, like me.)2: It's unique. There is no game like this. ANywhere. It simulates a solar system (simplified, of course, because truly doing this in real time is beyond any home computer.) so that you can build, fly and crash rockets, planes, boats and... anything. The limitations are almost nonexistent. Some youtubes build completely stock (No mods) helicopters even though there are no parts designed to build a helicopter. 3: You HAVE to think. You can slap rockets together and hope for the best and plenty of people have mastered this game from doing that. But if you don't learn and try, this game will lose appeal fast. If you manage to get over the steep learning curve, though, you'll never get bored of this game. Minecraft let you let your artistry go wild. This game will refine it into a diamond as you struggle to meld Form and Function into spacecraft that can literally go beyond the Moon. I can't be serious enough in saying that this is a truly fascinating and amazing game.4: Mod support. There are mods that give you exactly the type of experience you're looking for. The stock game is wonderful and enough for most people to sink their teeth into for a good minute. If you want more, there are mods that enhance and maintain a stock-a-like experience and mods that add completely new systems. Or bananas. Hell, there's a mod that lets you make a Hamburger that you can launch into space. Why? I dunno.Anyways, this game is worth playing for anybody. It's unique, offers limitless challenge and, if you're patient, it will actually teach you about aerospace. It won't make you an astronaut, but if you show up to space camp after a few hundred hours of this game you'll definitely have some knowledge to show off.

												Awesome, realistic space ship building game where you can explore a solar system of another race.In this game, you start a space program, the Kerbal Space Program. Start by building your first ship, may it be a sattelite or something massive, as you launch it into space. But do not expect it to go smoothly at first, expect lots of crew members to die, and lots of explosions to happen before you even create a space-capable ship.It's refreshing, challenging and something to feel accomplished of when succeeding. Though in alpha state still, the game proves to have extremely alot of potential, definately a recommendation even in it's current state.So, if you're looking for a space game, that is challenging, fun, and realistic, do not hesitate buying this, as it's in alpha, it's a fair warning to say that the game is far from finished.Also, personally, I can't even get a rocket into orbit, as I constantly crash down. content:
Posted: February 28, 2014
Early Access Review
								Never has a game made me feel so accomplished. Few games capture the beauty and adventure of the unknown quite like Kerbal Space Program. Building your own complex spaceship, rover, spacestation, or lunar base is quick and easy, and there is no telling where your imagination might take you next. From the moon, to gas giants, to Mars look-alikes, Kerbal Space Program will give you countless hours of adventure, fun, creativity, and even a few laughs. You might even learn a few things along the way. If you enjoy interstellar sandbox games with a realistic twist KSP is definitely for you. Five Stars - Excellent game.

content:
Posted: February 21, 2014
Early Access Review
								This one flew under the radar...I saw this game a few times while looking for something to play, never really stopping to pick it up.Finally, out of bordem, I checked out the forums.  Seemed there weren't many negative reviews, some game play issues, but nothing too crazy.  So, for ♥♥♥♥♥ and giggles, I downloaded it.Best decision I've made since burning down the neighbours house!! You are able to build rockets, blast your Kerbals into space, and leave them stranded on the dark side of some long lost ice-planet because you failed to remember to give them a way home.There is a career mode, which starts you out with almost nothing and as you accomplish more and more objectives, gives you points to buy more equipment.  There is also a sandbox mode which gives you everything all at once so you can start building your double-wide rocket right away.This game has a MASSIVE sense of achievement.  There is a bit of a leaning curve to accomplish some of the more advanced things (ie: landing on the Mun (moon) or flying to another planet), but when you finally get all your ducks in a row make it, it is truly an awesome feeling.  Not many games have that kind of effect.Therefore:If you are any kind of space fan or love the space program, this game is definitely for you.If you like building rockets with realistic physics modelling.. this game is for you.If you like watching your kerbals go up in flames because you failed to secure your rocket and it turned into a bees nest of fire and metal... this game is for you.If you hate space and anything fun, ... this game is NOT for you.Good luck and plan accordingly!:)

content:
Posted: June 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								I absolutely LOVE this game.  I definitely recommend it if you love space/space exploration as much as I do.  The physics aren't exactly 'real world' but for a simulator they are phenomenal.  If you're a trial and error kind of person, you'll enjoy it.  If you're a patient person, you'll enjoy it.  If you're a person able to learn things, you'll enjoy it.  There really aren't any full tutorials in game, but the kerbal wiki is rich with material.  It's still early access, but for an early access game it's definitely blown me away.  You start off at a space center on an earth-like planet 'Kerbin.'  You can then either build a rocket from scratch or load a pre-made one; I recommend the latter just to get a feel for the game.  Once you know what you're doing, you can pretty much decide what you're doing from there.  They've added a career mode recently, and I think it holds some promise.  So far you perform launches with a limited amount of parts for your rockets and conduct experiments at different altitudes and locations.  Those experiments will get you 'science points' which are spent to research a new technology on a tech-tree.  The said techonology will unlock more parts for your ship to further your launches which in turn further your experiments.  More points, more parts, more research.  It goes on.  Career mode is still in development so I expect a lot more from it in the future.

content:
Posted: June 7, 2016
												In this game you control every aspect of a space mission, from hiring your crew, to researching technologies, to designing your ship, to launching it into orbit, landing it on another planet (or moon), and safely returning your crew home.WARNING: THIS GAME IS VERY HARDIt is literally rocket science. You will have to learn all about rocket design, staging, and orbital mechanics in order to successfully send your kerbals to the mun and back. You will fail many times, usually resulting in spectacular explosions. But when you finally succeed, and your hours and hours of research, trial and error finally pay off, it is the most satisfying feeling of any video game I have ever played. When your kerbal steps out of the spaceship you designed and piloted, climbs down the ladder, plants the flag, and you look up to admire the beautiful view of kerbin from the mun, you suddenly feel that all those hours of frustration were worth it.

Seemed there weren't many negative reviews, some game play issues, but nothing too crazy.  So, for ♥♥♥♥♥ and giggles, I downloaded it.Best decision I've made since burning down the neighbours house!! You are able to build rockets, blast your Kerbals into space, and leave them stranded on the dark side of some long lost ice-planet because you failed to remember to give them a way home.There is a career mode, which starts you out with almost nothing and as you accomplish more and more objectives, gives you points to buy more equipment.  There is also a sandbox mode which gives you everything all at once so you can start building your double-wide rocket right away.This game has a MASSIVE sense of achievement.  There is a bit of a leaning curve to accomplish some of the more advanced things (ie: landing on the Mun (moon) or flying to another planet), but when you finally get all your ducks in a row make it, it is truly an awesome feeling.  Not many games have that kind of effect.Therefore:If you are any kind of space fan or love the space program, this game is definitely for you.If you like building rockets with realistic physics modelling.. this game is for you.If you like watching your kerbals go up in flames because you failed to secure your rocket and it turned into a bees nest of fire and metal... this game is for you.If you hate space and anything fun, ... this game is NOT for you.Good luck and plan accordingly!:)

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								I love this game.Kerbal Space Program is a sandbox space exploration simulator that totes a very realistic physics system. The challenge of the game is build a rocket that has the potential to reach distant moons or planets, but that's only half the game! You must also pilot that rocket successfully to reach your goal.With the amount of attachments you can put on your rocket, the possibilities are endless. You can build: a space shuttle, a space station, a moon rover, sattelites, retrieval rockets, moon bases and more. The only things that limit you will be your skill and imagination.While there really is no 'goal' to the game, it is still very satisfying all the same. The first time I landed on Mun I stood up out of my chair and shot my arms into the air! The very next thing was posting a screenshot to Facebook. When you first play the game and see the moon in the sky, you immediately want to start buidling a rocket that can reach it! This makes the game super fun to play, because the 'goals' or 'winning conditions' are based upon what you want as a gamer.tl;dr - If you are thinking about buying this game stop killing time and buy it. The sheer number of rocket outcomes and flight possibilities are unfathomable. Kerbal Space Program will make your wonder and dream of space exploration come alive!

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful2 people found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 11, 2015
												Tip for Kerbal Space Program players: Hitting Alt+F4 does not bring Bob Kerman back from playing with his jetpack on the moon, flying 40+ m/s into the side of a crater. Hitting Alt+F4 does also not fill Jedebiah Kerman with EVA propellant so he can get back to his orbiting space ship. Hitting Alt+F4 also does not reverse the 40 minutes you spent getting to Duna, only to realize you forgot Newke Kerman. Hitting Alt+F4 does not revive your sanity after going back to your vehicle assembly, putting Newke Kerman in your pod, flying back to Duna, and not having enough fuel to slow yourself down, going 30 m/s over the limit, and killing Newke Kerman. Hitting Alt+F4 also does not make you feel less stupid about getting rid of your landing rockets, and putting on four parachutes because you realized that Duna has an atmosphere. Hitting Alt+F4 saves you from embarrassment when you pull up your steam overlay, and realize you messed up your amazing trajectory to Minmus by hitting the Shift key to pull up the Steam overlay, only to do it again and tell your friend about how you're stressed and angry because you just messed up your path to Minmus, only to be cut short because you made yourself an escape trajectory out of Kerbin because once again, you hit Shift.

If you get bored with the 'stock' game, take a look at the mod community. Dedicated individuals have created mods that can change just about every aspect of the game adding new parts, research, game tools, textures, etc. Buy KSP now!!

Posted: March 21, 2013
												Awesome, realistic space ship building game where you can explore a solar system of another race.In this game, you start a space program, the Kerbal Space Program. Start by building your first ship, may it be a sattelite or something massive, as you launch it into space. But do not expect it to go smoothly at first, expect lots of crew members to die, and lots of explosions to happen before you even create a space-capable ship.It's refreshing, challenging and something to feel accomplished of when succeeding. Though in alpha state still, the game proves to have extremely alot of potential, definately a recommendation even in it's current state.So, if you're looking for a space game, that is challenging, fun, and realistic, do not hesitate buying this, as it's in alpha, it's a fair warning to say that the game is far from finished.Also, personally, I can't even get a rocket into orbit, as I constantly crash down. content:
Posted: December 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								Kerbal Space Program went public only a few month short before Kickstarter became big, so keep that in mind when you play that unlike some Early Access games KSP didn't have a huge fundraiser at  the start.  Their success is purely due to their own hard work.And that they do.  The game is updated at  a steady pace.  Once very few months.  But the content additions have always been massive.  They're always pretty bug free as well.The game is also very easy to mod, adding so much replay value.  And do't just take my  word for it, you can literally go in and edit numbers in the notepag file for parts and make the part work totally differantly.Squad has proven themselves one of the greatest indie developers out there now.  If anything is testament to that it's the fan base.  Unlike other game fanbases, their's is almost entirely positive.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 28, 2016
												I've been playing KSP for a few weeks at this point and have made it all the way to obriting the Mun.Each successful mission has been an ever more impressive triumph which requires a greater depth of understanding and strategy, in asset allocation, construction, mission planning, and execution.I just went skydiving for the first time today. It was beyond words. Amazingly I followed every step in sequence at exactly the right altitudes without my instructor having to remind me. All while screaming toward the ground at up to 120 miles an hour. My instructor was so impressed that she let me land us at the end of the parachute coast after free fall.After it was over I couldn't shake the feeling that I had just successfully landed on the Mun.No game should be so good that you land from a skydive you feel the same exhileration and pride you do from playing it. A trip to the Mun is way more exciting than "a trip to Pittsburg", and it's worth the hard knocks to figure out how to get there.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: November 27, 2016
												You spent hours building that rover just right. Not too much or too little fuel and propulsion, and the craft is properly reinforced with struts (of course).You spent even more time flying the craft to it's destination. The staging was perfect, the orbits calculated just right.Finally, you spend many nerve-wracking minutes landing the rover. In the end, the descent goes without fail, with just enough fuel.There was some sticky moments, but now you are at your destination. You made it to space today, and now it's time to science. You start driving the rover, celebrating your success...Only to realize the rover is not as balanced as you thought, which causes it to fly up and spin out of control in microgravity and explode into 5 million pieces when it strikes the surface.You realize then you forgot Rule #1: Failure is always an option.11/10 Always good for making you question your own intelligence and self-esteem.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 27, 2016
												This is a truly unique game. This is a truly infuriating game.There's nothing I can say bad about this game because 1: I'd call it about 90% stable (compared to a bethesda game that's about 70%). This alone wouldn't matter. Just cuz the game loads and doesn't crash while you play it doesn't mean it's not bad. But for how much time the average Kerbal will play this game, it's a huge factor (Also, the game takes about 10 minutes to load if you have anywhere near 100 mods installed, like me.)2: It's unique. There is no game like this. ANywhere. It simulates a solar system (simplified, of course, because truly doing this in real time is beyond any home computer.) so that you can build, fly and crash rockets, planes, boats and... anything. The limitations are almost nonexistent. Some youtubes build completely stock (No mods) helicopters even though there are no parts designed to build a helicopter. 3: You HAVE to think. You can slap rockets together and hope for the best and plenty of people have mastered this game from doing that. But if you don't learn and try, this game will lose appeal fast. If you manage to get over the steep learning curve, though, you'll never get bored of this game. Minecraft let you let your artistry go wild. This game will refine it into a diamond as you struggle to meld Form and Function into spacecraft that can literally go beyond the Moon. I can't be serious enough in saying that this is a truly fascinating and amazing game.4: Mod support. There are mods that give you exactly the type of experience you're looking for. The stock game is wonderful and enough for most people to sink their teeth into for a good minute. If you want more, there are mods that enhance and maintain a stock-a-like experience and mods that add completely new systems. Or bananas. Hell, there's a mod that lets you make a Hamburger that you can launch into space. Why? I dunno.Anyways, this game is worth playing for anybody. It's unique, offers limitless challenge and, if you're patient, it will actually teach you about aerospace. It won't make you an astronaut, but if you show up to space camp after a few hundred hours of this game you'll definitely have some knowledge to show off.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								I love this game.Kerbal Space Program is a sandbox space exploration simulator that totes a very realistic physics system. The challenge of the game is build a rocket that has the potential to reach distant moons or planets, but that's only half the game! You must also pilot that rocket successfully to reach your goal.With the amount of attachments you can put on your rocket, the possibilities are endless. You can build: a space shuttle, a space station, a moon rover, sattelites, retrieval rockets, moon bases and more. The only things that limit you will be your skill and imagination.While there really is no 'goal' to the game, it is still very satisfying all the same. The first time I landed on Mun I stood up out of my chair and shot my arms into the air! The very next thing was posting a screenshot to Facebook. When you first play the game and see the moon in the sky, you immediately want to start buidling a rocket that can reach it! This makes the game super fun to play, because the 'goals' or 'winning conditions' are based upon what you want as a gamer.tl;dr - If you are thinking about buying this game stop killing time and buy it. The sheer number of rocket outcomes and flight possibilities are unfathomable. Kerbal Space Program will make your wonder and dream of space exploration come alive!

content:
Posted: January 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								My train of thought from before I bought it to now:- I see my friends playing it a bunch, but will I like it? Im worried I'll get bored since space isnt really my forte.- I start watching broadcasts by other steam users and asking them questions about its replayability- Oh, it has modding support, which apparently is a must in this game- After hours of research and streaming, I bought it on sale for $22- I was still skeptical   - At first I started out in science mode (gain tech points, no money system) which was one of the harder modes. oops.   - Next I tried career mode, which offered contracts for those of us who wanted to gain science (tech) and where also newer to the game.   - Oh, there are spaceplanes?   - *Download many mods*   - Oh, there are _______? (x10)   - Unlock more tech to perfect my plane   - *Download more mods*   - Planes that run off of electricity?   - Nuclear....That's where I'm at, and Im loving every bit of it. I've always been kind of a ship-builder guy when it comes to free-roam exploration games like this (If you do too, check out reassembly), but it's captivated me. Im always told to pay attention to Delta V (Change in velocity) which I assume is important, but I'm too new to the game to get into specifics like that. Super fun!

content:
Posted: August 11, 2015
												Tip for Kerbal Space Program players: Hitting Alt+F4 does not bring Bob Kerman back from playing with his jetpack on the moon, flying 40+ m/s into the side of a crater. Hitting Alt+F4 does also not fill Jedebiah Kerman with EVA propellant so he can get back to his orbiting space ship. Hitting Alt+F4 also does not reverse the 40 minutes you spent getting to Duna, only to realize you forgot Newke Kerman. Hitting Alt+F4 does not revive your sanity after going back to your vehicle assembly, putting Newke Kerman in your pod, flying back to Duna, and not having enough fuel to slow yourself down, going 30 m/s over the limit, and killing Newke Kerman. Hitting Alt+F4 also does not make you feel less stupid about getting rid of your landing rockets, and putting on four parachutes because you realized that Duna has an atmosphere. Hitting Alt+F4 saves you from embarrassment when you pull up your steam overlay, and realize you messed up your amazing trajectory to Minmus by hitting the Shift key to pull up the Steam overlay, only to do it again and tell your friend about how you're stressed and angry because you just messed up your path to Minmus, only to be cut short because you made yourself an escape trajectory out of Kerbin because once again, you hit Shift.

content:
Posted: August 28, 2016
												I've been playing KSP for a few weeks at this point and have made it all the way to obriting the Mun.Each successful mission has been an ever more impressive triumph which requires a greater depth of understanding and strategy, in asset allocation, construction, mission planning, and execution.I just went skydiving for the first time today. It was beyond words. Amazingly I followed every step in sequence at exactly the right altitudes without my instructor having to remind me. All while screaming toward the ground at up to 120 miles an hour. My instructor was so impressed that she let me land us at the end of the parachute coast after free fall.After it was over I couldn't shake the feeling that I had just successfully landed on the Mun.No game should be so good that you land from a skydive you feel the same exhileration and pride you do from playing it. A trip to the Mun is way more exciting than "a trip to Pittsburg", and it's worth the hard knocks to figure out how to get there.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 19, 2016
												Kerbal Space Program. Oh, Kerbal Space Program. I don't know what to say.Ok. Here is what I'm going to say. KSP has done a lot for me, and I'm glad that I finally got a new PC capable of playing it on a playable level (I don't know how I ever enjoyed it before on my 5 year old laptop, much less reach over 700 hours). But I probably reached that level for 2 reasons: 1. I left the game idle a lot and 2. Simply because KSP is such a great game.If you hadn't read the description up there, KSP is a game where you must manage your space program and send you kerbal astronauts safely into space.KSP's main mode is carrer mode, where you run a space program, and you have to make sure you can efficiently get your spacecraft to fly straight and make it safely into space (and safely return home too). You also have to manage your money by accepting contracts and complete research by collecting "science" to unlock new and better parts.My favorite mode, however, is sandbox mode, where you can build any aircraft/spacecraft/rover/boat/drone/car etc. you want. I personally enjoy designing my own airplanes. It is also a good place to practice your building and flying skills before you try career mode.KSP shines it's best when building. As said before, you have unlimited options to build whatever you want. There are hundreds of different parts for you to choose, and can be placed in pretty much any way you want on your craft. The system of building is very intuitive, as parts that have a similar shape will snap together, and you can easily mount parts on the side of other parts and rotate and move them using tools to put them wherever you want.KSP's physics engine is best compared to actual physics. In other words, it's extremely realistic. Spacecraft will generally fly as they would in real life, and real life spaceflight manuvers are plausible ways of navigating in KSP. When flying, a helpful array of instruments will tell you your speed, altitude (relative to nearest body), direction, and atmospheric density. The aerodynamic flight model is also very realistic, so if designing aircraft is your thing, you will surely enjoy KSP.If I haven't made it clear already, KSP deals with ACTUAL ROCKET SCIENCE (no I'm not exaggerating). So while it's accessible, don't expect a walk in the park. Even with it's tutorials, KSP is VERY DIFFICULT. However, the way Squad dealt with easing the pain of learning rocket science was genius. They made the game HILARIOUS!!! The cute, green, clumsy kerbals that pilot your aircraft will generally have facial expressions regarding your current situation, so they will be in awe when you reach the Mun (the in game equivilent to the Moon), but will be screaming in terror when you are crashing to the ground. If you crash, which you are bound to do a lot, don't feel bad for killing all your kerbals, thanks to the helpful "revert flight" button that turns back time and makes it so that the crash never happened. Speaking of time, the game's "timewarp" feature is capable of turning time up to 100,000x faster than current time, and is helpful when you are doing long, interplanetary missions. KSP doesn't get much regard for it's graphics, but I think they look good, and when you are orbiting a gas giant with 5 moons, the game can look pretty incredible. Speaking of planets, there are a total of 17 different celestial bodies (planets, moons, and stars) for you to explore! Finally, KSP has an amazing modding community. There are mods that add new parts, new mechanics to the game, alter the physics to make the game even more realistic, some that add more planets, and there is even a mod that adds online multiplayer to KSP! So if you ever get bored of the core game (something that is very unlikely to happen), be sure to check out the mods that have been created!KSP has been an influential game in my life. It's helped me make friends, it's boosted my interest in aviation, aerospace, and space exploration. It's helped me get into new hobbies such as flight simming, RC flying, and model rockets. And it's even inspired me to think about what I want to do with my life one day, even if it has absolutely nothing to do with KSP. Kerbal Space Program has really been a lifechanging experience, and is arguably my favorite video game ever. I wish I could give it higher than a 10 on a 1 to 10 scale, but since I can't, KSP easily recieves a 10/10 from me. Be sure to pick it up for yourself, and make sure to get it when it's on sale!

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
Early Access Review
								This is one of the best games I have ever played.  It is an indie game and not yet in full release, but the developers are highly communicative with the community and regular updates are released almost always adding major features or bug fixes.  The modding community is extremely dedicated and the developers are highly supportive of it to the point where they have hired several of the best modders straight from the community.I've put over 250 hours into this game since its been on Steam, but that doesn't count the hundreds of hours I put in before it was on Steam.The game is extremely worth it and has an extremely bright future ahead of it.  There is no clear objective system at the moment though, which has turned some people off the game.  I don't believe its coming in the next update but their main priority is currently fleshing out the 'career' mode (as opposed to the sandbox mode that most people play) where there will be objectives, funding, and research.  Research has already been added but it needs some major fixing, which is actually their expressed priority for the coming update.TLDR; The game is very much worth it, if you're interested in spacetravel at all go for it.  The satisfaction of landing on the Mun (Kerbal equivalent of the Moon) on your own for the first time more than makes it worth the cost, not to mention the hundreds of other things there are for you to do.Oh, and if you're still on the fence there is a free demo for you to try.  It only includes a fraction of the parts and celestial bodies that are available in the full version and does not include the career mode, but it gives you a good idea of what the full game is like.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 30, 2014
												PROS:Modding support. The developers encourage modding and the modding community for this game is pretty big. While modding extends a game's life and increases enjoyment you can easily have fun with the stock unmodified game. I would reccomend Engineer, MechJeb and Kerbal Attachment System to start.Easy to start. You don't need to know a thing about real world rocketry to play this. There are in-game tutorials for most of the game aspects and the community has written out details about the advanced stuff.(Mostly) Friendly community.While every community has its share of "not nice" people, KSP has an invested fan base who will help and support each other. Don't know about a certain thing in the game? You won't be ridiculed for not knowing everything.Quicksaving and reverting are enabled.Afraid to take some of the Kerbal crew you have grown attached to on a dangerous mission? Have no fear, saves are here! F5 quicksaves the game while F9 reloads the quicksave. Need to take a few tries before you successfully do a powered landing? Just quicksave. Crash terribly before you had the chance to save? Revert to the launchpad. For people who don't like to quicksave it is 100% optional.Not stuck to one flight.Don't feel like time accelerating while waiting for your deep space probe's course correction? No problem! Just switch to another ship, your probe will still make progress. A mod called "Kerbal Alarm Clock" is great for letting you know when your ships need to be paid attention to.NASA street cred.For KSP's 23.5 update they actually worked with NASA to add things to the game. While the game isn't 100% realistic you can tell that the developers are balancing realism with unrealistic things.Demo available.More games should come with a "try before you buy" feature and demos are a great way of giving that. If you are really unsure about if the game is for you, get the demo.Rewarding gameplay.Knowing the ship you created landed on the Mun, or even made it into Kerbin orbit, is a great feeling. Being able to bring your crew home safely is also great. I remember my first attempt at a crewed landing on the Mun. I didn't have enough fuel to land on the Mun so I sent an unmanned ship to refuel it using the KAS mod. After refueling I landed on the Mun after several tries. I planted my flag and launched back into orbit only to realize that I didn't have enough fuel to get back so I rendezvoused with the refueling vessel. When I finally made it back to Kerbin and splash downed in the ocean it was a great feeling.CONS:Not everyone can pick up and play.Some people will not be able to figure out the game and will think it is too complicated. There is online material to help with understanding the game but that might not be enough.==I have spent more time on this game than any other game. I enjoy it that much. More than half my time is spent designing vessels but I am learning more and more. Often I will not have played the game for a few days when I feel it pulling me back in. I definitely recommend this game.

content:
Posted: March 21
												Overall - Very silly and fun. However, first warning - Buy it on sale of at least $20 or less if possible. NOT worth the current $40 being asked for.Pro's: It's fun to build something just to see what happens and how far you can get them up there. Strap on a bunch of rockets, a few struts, then more rockets, about three layers high, then add a command seat for one very nervous Kerbal and you end up either having a fun time, or a barbecue. Either way, fun is had by all.Different modes of play allow you to try different things for the fun of it, including what amounts to creative mode.There's an inbuilt cheat mode, as well, I've recently learned. Look it up if you care. I'm not sure what it does beyond give money and ... maybe science points? o.O'Cons:So, first thing to know. Increasing the speed of play during launch or at any point really during a launch and flight, will actually cause physics to go wonky when they otherwise wouldn't.Figuring out how to make and control the more advanced builds have been difficult for me. Tutorials gave a touch of aid, but not enough to really be helpful.Overall: 7/10 - Mainly due to difficulty and lack of tutorials that really give decent data. Still fun to build random things and see if you can crash into a moon or the run.-Paladeus

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 30, 2014
												PROS:Modding support. The developers encourage modding and the modding community for this game is pretty big. While modding extends a game's life and increases enjoyment you can easily have fun with the stock unmodified game. I would reccomend Engineer, MechJeb and Kerbal Attachment System to start.Easy to start. You don't need to know a thing about real world rocketry to play this. There are in-game tutorials for most of the game aspects and the community has written out details about the advanced stuff.(Mostly) Friendly community.While every community has its share of "not nice" people, KSP has an invested fan base who will help and support each other. Don't know about a certain thing in the game? You won't be ridiculed for not knowing everything.Quicksaving and reverting are enabled.Afraid to take some of the Kerbal crew you have grown attached to on a dangerous mission? Have no fear, saves are here! F5 quicksaves the game while F9 reloads the quicksave. Need to take a few tries before you successfully do a powered landing? Just quicksave. Crash terribly before you had the chance to save? Revert to the launchpad. For people who don't like to quicksave it is 100% optional.Not stuck to one flight.Don't feel like time accelerating while waiting for your deep space probe's course correction? No problem! Just switch to another ship, your probe will still make progress. A mod called "Kerbal Alarm Clock" is great for letting you know when your ships need to be paid attention to.NASA street cred.For KSP's 23.5 update they actually worked with NASA to add things to the game. While the game isn't 100% realistic you can tell that the developers are balancing realism with unrealistic things.Demo available.More games should come with a "try before you buy" feature and demos are a great way of giving that. If you are really unsure about if the game is for you, get the demo.Rewarding gameplay.Knowing the ship you created landed on the Mun, or even made it into Kerbin orbit, is a great feeling. Being able to bring your crew home safely is also great. I remember my first attempt at a crewed landing on the Mun. I didn't have enough fuel to land on the Mun so I sent an unmanned ship to refuel it using the KAS mod. After refueling I landed on the Mun after several tries. I planted my flag and launched back into orbit only to realize that I didn't have enough fuel to get back so I rendezvoused with the refueling vessel. When I finally made it back to Kerbin and splash downed in the ocean it was a great feeling.CONS:Not everyone can pick up and play.Some people will not be able to figure out the game and will think it is too complicated. There is online material to help with understanding the game but that might not be enough.==I have spent more time on this game than any other game. I enjoy it that much. More than half my time is spent designing vessels but I am learning more and more. Often I will not have played the game for a few days when I feel it pulling me back in. I definitely recommend this game.

content:
Posted: May 1, 2015
												“Look again at that dot. That's here. That's home. That's us. On it everyone you love, everyone you know, everyone you ever heard of, every human being who ever was, lived out their lives. The aggregate of our joy and suffering, thousands of confident religions, ideologies, and economic doctrines, every hunter and forager, every hero and coward, every creator and destroyer of civilization, every king and peasant, every young couple in love, every mother and father, hopeful child, inventor and explorer, every teacher of morals, every corrupt politician, every "superstar," every "supreme leader," every saint and sinner in the history of our species lived there-on a mote of dust suspended in a sunbeam.The Earth is a very small stage in a vast cosmic arena. Think of the endless cruelties visited by the inhabitants of one corner of this pixel on the scarcely distinguishable inhabitants of some other corner, how frequent their misunderstandings, how eager they are to kill one another, how fervent their hatreds. Think of the rivers of blood spilled by all those generals and emperors so that, in glory and triumph, they could become the momentary masters of a fraction of a dot.Our posturings, our imagined self-importance, the delusion that we have some privileged position in the Universe, are challenged by this point of pale light. Our planet is a lonely speck in the great enveloping cosmic dark. In our obscurity, in all this vastness, there is no hint that help will come from elsewhere to save us from ourselves.The Earth is the only world known so far to harbor life. There is nowhere else, at least in the near future, to which our species could migrate. Visit, yes. Settle, not yet. Like it or not, for the moment the Earth is where we make our stand.It has been said that astronomy is a humbling and character-building experience. There is perhaps no better demonstration of the folly of human conceits than this distant image of our tiny world. To me, it underscores our responsibility to deal more kindly with one another, and to preserve and cherish the pale blue dot, the only home we've ever known.”- Carl Sagan

content:
Posted: April 3, 2016
												If you like space and building things, you'll like Kerbal Space Program. The graphics are mostly so-so, but gameplay is excellent. There's no artificial sense of achievement; you set your own goals and work hard to achieve them. At first, the game will feel really difficult, but as you master the real physics behind the game, you'll be able to go bigger and grander. The base game feels complete, but mods add a lot more to the experience. Overall, an amazing game with tremendous replay value. 10/10
