number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 28, 2015
												KSP is one of the best games I have ever played. It is as tense and exciting as Bioshock. It is as challenging as Darksouls, but is 1000 times more forgiving. It is the biggest sandbox I have ever played in, and I feel like wherever I go there is meaning in my progress. It does a better job at giving you a story to weave than any RPG thus far… though I might be getting a bit into hyperbole. It’s just hard to not to, in the light of just how FANTASTIC this game is. I have over three times the number of hours displayed on steam due to my use of modded installs which I run without steam.TLDR at bottomThe AwesomeYou can play any way you want. Heck, you might never leave orbit of Kerbin (Earth's analog in the game: your home) and spend your time making supersonic aircraft and rovers to explore Kerbin's surface. Of course, I wouldn't recommend that, as then you would be missing out on the wonders of space exploration... but to each their own. It is super accessible. Orbital mechanics can get complicated. I do that stuff in school. It can get pretty crazy. But have no fear! Squad’s map screen will let you add Maneuver Nodes, allowing you to see what your orbit will look like if you burn in a certain direction. This lets you learn orbital mechanics through an intuitive trial and error process.You can explore the game’s solar system in any manner you deem feasible, with whatever vehicles you can dream up (and successfully get off the ground). You can send probes into the sun, aerobrake around gas planets, land rovers on moons, and generally be cool floating around in space. Experience different game modes! Creative lets you play with all the parts, and not worry about unlocking anything or paying for it. Science makes you unlock parts with SCIENCE!, but you don’t have to pay for anything or worry about your Rep. Career is where you manage all the aspects of your space program, dealing with Funds, SCIENCE!, and Reputation in order to get your Space Program to the heights of success. I’ll explain each of those “resources” below.Gain SCIENCE! by running around making observations and running experiments wherever you see fit, or by completing missions you sign up for. Use this SCIENCE! to unlock new parts for your space program. Manage your Funds carefully, and with great concern, as you will need every penny you have to upgrade facilities, hire your brave astronauts, and launch your craft into the great unknown. Make money by accepting missions, which range from testing out a part on the launch pad, to launching a tourist to the moon, to setting up a base on the surface of Laythe (a moon of the game's analogue of Jupiter) capable of resource extraction and the support of 30 Kerbals. No matter the complexity no mission is impossible.Make sure you keep your Reputation in check as well, as even though I am not sure what it actually effects, you can convert a percentage of your Reputation gains into the far more useful SCIENCE! points and Funds. Perhaps Reputation will play a greater role in updates, or there is a hidden purpose to it which I have yet to discover.Level up your Kerbals RPG style by having them go and do things they haven’t yet done! Pilots gain the ability to keep the craft oriented to a specific direction. You can’t set your heading or anything, but you can ask to keep the ship pointed retrograde during re-entry, or towards a maneuver node. 1st level pilots can only point Prograde and retrograde, but more are unlocked per level. Scientists gain the ability to reset experiments and give you even greater returns of SCIENCE!. Engineers gain the ability to fix busted parts like wheels, though their effect is somewhat limited, as most parts simply explode when they break.The game is rarely tedious, as even the longest transfer times can be compressed into a few minutes with the game's time acceleration, and even when you are forced to wait, you can look at beautiful vistas of the sun peeking out from behind the planet, or marvel at your design as it floats (or spins uncontrollably) in space.Rendezvous with and redirect asteroids! Because it’s cool! You can get SCIENCE! from them, slam them into other craft or celestial bodies, land them on the roofs of your facilities, or build a space station on them. They’re just fun.Burn up as you scream through the atmosphere at thousands of meters per second. This most recent release has made re-entry rather… dangerous. You have to design your craft with the concept of a “return journey” in mind, and having the craft accidently flip around during re-entry, exposing your squishy crew cabins to the intense heat of friction, and then struggling with the controls to get the heat shield pointed back in the direction of travel is probably one of the most intense experiences I have ever had in a game. Whether you succeed or fail, it is still unbelievably cool to do it in first person.The MOAR AwesomeAnd the best part? That, and more which I haven’t mentioned, are ONLY what COMES WITH the game. There is a catalogue of THOUSANDS of mods to add on to your game, very easily too, which can drastically improve the game beyond even what it is now. Mods adding entire new resourcing ecosystems (Kethane/Karbonite), mods adding hundreds of parts (LLL/B9),  and mods adding entirely new features (Hanger/Weather mods).Mods adding useful functions (Kerbal Engineer), mods adding cool sound effects, and  mods making the game look photo realistic (Texture Replacer).Mods ADDING MULTIPLAYER (DMP), mods adding weapons and new damage models, and mods adding ROBOTICS (Infernal Robotics).Mods adding KERBAL BASED CONSTRUCTION (KAS), mods adding EXTRAPLANETARY LAUNCHPADS (Extraplanetary Launchpads), mods adding FLIPPING WARP DRIVES AND FUSION POWERED PLASMA ENGINES (Interstellar Mod), and so much more. So, so much more. And you know what is even better than that? YOU, yes YOU, are capable of editing text files. You are able to mod any part you can imagine. Fuel scoops that collect particles from space for your ion engine probe to use? Yes, you can do that with like four lines in a text file. It truly is a sandbox, and you can spend just as much time having fun with the game files as you would actually playing the game. The Slightly Less AwesomeDespite KSP’s greatness, there are some small issues, Mainly the lack of a stable 64 bit build for Windows.As I have pointed out, modding can make the game a whole lot more awesome right off the bat. However, KSP keeps all of its Game Data files in its memory at all times. This normally wouldn’t be a problem; KSP only has about 1 Gb to manage without any mods, and even though KSP on windows is only 32bit, it has plenty of ram to work from.As you might imagine however, when you start having a parts list that grows to 2000+ parts, KSP might start to get a bit on its memory. When you develop a Game Data folder that starts getting to 3-3.5 Gb of size, KSP will start to crash. A lot.As KSP isn’t going to change how to it handles asset loading, the most obvious change to make to allow people to have a stupid number of mods would be to release a 64 bit build. Unfortunately, KSP is built with Unity. And 64 bit windows Unity is really buggy. Buggy to the point where Squad didn’t release a 64 bit KSP for 1.0, as they didn’t want to release a hot mess. And Squad can’t really do anything about it until Unity fixes the issues. I would like to point out that this is absolutely ZERO reason to not buy the game; I just complained about KSP because it crashes when I mod it too much. So go, shell out that 30 USD. It may just be the best 30 dollars you will ever spend.TLDRBottom Line: 10/10- Would save Jeb from certain death again.Ad Astra

Early Access Review
								Fun and realistic space program simulation. Pretend to build your own NASA program, research, build rockets, launch them into space, land on the "Mun" or go further to distant planets, build your own ISS, rescue your stranded Kerbals, race around in a mun-buggy, build your personal space shuttle.Or combine everything in sandbox mode.Great fun.

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								Kerbal Space Program....More like Endless Fun Program! If you like to build, test, observe, re-build, then grab your hard-hat and engineering degree (metaphorically speaking) and download Kerbal Space Program.Campaign and creative modes each allowing you to fulfill the exciting task of exploring outer space. Developers release regular updates which include interface updates as well as new parts to install on your spacecraft. There are lots of mods to install as well to tailor your KSP experience.One point to note is that the tutorial mode does a fair job in explaining the basics of spacecraft design, however, it does not explain what all of the parts do. New players may be at a loss as to what some of the parts are used for, thus forcing them to go searching for explanations on these parts.

content:
Posted: November 21, 2015
												An amazing game. I've logged so many hours in this one. The reward/investment ratio is practically infinite.Do rocket science by trial and error, or crunch the numbers and design the perfect system. Build a space station, create a lunar colony, fly to other planets and science them. On top of the vanilla game, it supports some serious modding abilities. There are tons of mods already out there - from silly to game-altering. Even tho the game is released, the developers have continued updated the systems with good, meaningful improvements.I have no reservations about recommending this game.

number of helpful: 4 of 6 people (67%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 31, 2015
												This may be the most fun I've ever had at my computer.....or my various console game machines...or in front of a coin-op cabinet game...or even much of anything else!   I was born a few months before Sputnik touched off the space race....and astronaut was at least near the top of every child's "what I wanna be" list.  It was number one on mine!  The magic of this game for me is it connects with that child who never achieved that pinnacle of human endeavor, but unlike other science fiction games that center around aliens and space battles,  this one recreates what we were actually doing in space, and lets me put all those children's books on how we were going to get into space to work.  I must admit it tickles me  to be able to outperform players who grew up in the post George Lucas gaming world who don't always grasp that space ships do not perform like jet fighter planes.....and why should they?  It may be centuries before we run into a hostile alien force....if in fact we ever do. As for me, the sheer joy and wonder of putting a space craft in orbit and looking down on the beautiful world below far outshines the number of enemy craft I've blown to space dust with my plama bolts or anti-matter missiles, or particle beams. There are mods that let you turn space int a war zone  if you must...meanwhile.I'll be on board the space station 'Evening Star', learning things from orbit that the groundhogs never guessed, and plotting the best course for Duna Discovery Fleet One.

												An amazing game. I've logged so many hours in this one. The reward/investment ratio is practically infinite.Do rocket science by trial and error, or crunch the numbers and design the perfect system. Build a space station, create a lunar colony, fly to other planets and science them. On top of the vanilla game, it supports some serious modding abilities. There are tons of mods already out there - from silly to game-altering. Even tho the game is released, the developers have continued updated the systems with good, meaningful improvements.I have no reservations about recommending this game.

content:
Posted: February 7, 2015
Early Access Review
								Quite the revolutionary game if you ask me. Not only do you get to build your own rockets, spaceplanes, and whatever else you can think of. You can also build your own learning curve as well! With the help of modifications that make the base game even easier or more difficult!Cannot get to the mun? Get a mod that can change engine specific impulse so you can travel further!Planted a flag on every planet and moon? Get a mod that makes the Kerbol system resemble ours on a 1:1 scale!Game crashing because of too many mods? There is a mod to fix that!Once you have mastered KSP in all it's glory there is still fun to be had. Especially because there are many things to master in the base game like: docking, spaceplanes, and of course not running out of fuel before reaching your destination so you can return to Kerbin. The community, and modmakers only make the game even more in depth and fun!You don't like modding your game? Kudos to you vanilla extremist, I still haven't even done everything in stock KSP yet. Just goes to show how much fun you can have in this game with plenty of things to do! Well worth it's price!10/10 Still haven't touched the spaceplane hangar

content:
Posted: August 19, 2016
												No Man's Sky, as hard as it may try, will never produce the feeling of landing your fearless-ish Kerbals on the Mun with their trusty-ish Munar lander after completing your well-ish thought out maneuvers from the Kerbal Space Station for the first or twenty-first time. Microsoft Flight Simulator will never produce the feeling of landing your aerocraft on the Kerbal Space Center runway. No other game on steam will or can teach one so much about orbital mechanics, aerodynamics, astrophsyics, aerophsyics, or rocket science. There's no other game on steam that will make you laugh as hard, or think as hard when you fail.  And there's no other game on steam with more skilled, more incredible modders, or such an incredibly friendly, helpful community. Also, explosions.I personally rate this game 10/10. Kraken Aproves.

content:
Posted: October 19, 2015
												Kerbal Space Program is the perfect combination between gaming, learning and the best damn community a game can wish for. With almost unlimited mods and tutorials you're pretty much settled to spend a load of fun hours in this game. The only negative point in my opinion is that for some people the challenge will be too much. You don't just go to the moon or fly by an interstellar planet like that, there will be a lot of planning, thinking and most of all; failure. Seriously, the difficulty of this game can make you lose your♥♥♥♥♥♥ Imagine this: you're a wedding planner and you've been planning for days, only to discover that you're one cupcake short when the wedding is almost over and because of this you can start all over. It's a bit like that, but can you imagine the satisfaction when you actually pull something off? It's a feeling no other game can give you, trust me.Also, what I mentioned before, the community is amazing. Ever heard of Scott Manley? You will after you buy this game. There are many more like him that make tutorials for doing the craziest stuff, and a load of others that make humorous video's using KSP. Then there are mods, that can make the experience that much more challenging, fun or realistic. So all together, I would definitely recommend this game. Unless of course you don't like a challenge that will tear your family apart. Have fun :)

GeneralWhat can I say. Hm. Kerbal Space Program is just fantastic. I've been playing since early alpha (before steam), only paying $10 at the time and from that it has grown. Physics are great and new features are just amazing. I would recommend this to anyone.My OpinionKSP has been my life for a long time now. I love it. Going to different planets, landing on planets (which a lot of new space games lack today), building rovers, jets and anything you set your mind to. KSP even has mod support so you should never become bored and I found that great. Though, it sometimes is not fun to play alone. I cannot wait for multiplayer.OverallHowever.. there is something I CANNOT wrap my head around (below):I find it funny people are paying full price when you can butcher a friend that hasn't converted to Steam yet to give you the game for free through the KSP website store.Great game and I recommend it.Rating: 10/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 30, 2013
Early Access Review
								Exploration, construction, flight, and laughs is what this game has to offer. Explore the planet you are on with a rover, make a rocket to deliver a payload to another planet or space station, or construct a space station. Build your vehicle for exploration and hope it withstands the acceleration, gravity, and atmospheric forces stressing it.  Laugh at the faces the Kerbals make as they hit the ground at 1000m/s and survive to bounce once. Also, there are a wide variety of addons to expand your experience and enjoyment including but not limited to; more detailed information, different parts, tools to help make tasks easier or even do some tasks for you, and resource mining.This is one of the most difficult games to learn I have ever played, and while still bare-bones compared to what it will be, one of my favorites. You can spend hours trying to complete just one objective, trying to put yourself in a circular orbit or dock your first piece to a space station, and remain entertained the whole time.

Early Access Review
								This game...Kerbal Space Program is amazing. It features a sandbox mode where the player has all of the parts unlocked from the start, and a career mode with a tech tree to work towards completing through research. You can do whatever you want. Build a space station, walk on a distant planet, complete tests and return to Kerbin!The developers not only update the game frequently, but really get involved with the community to see what we like and dislike, want and don't want. The KSP forums are always active and people love sharing their fun experiences with each other.

content:

Early Access Review
								I first bought this game around v0.18 ish as enjoyed building crazy rockets and firing them into space. But for a beginner, it was pretty tough to learn how to play without understanding what's actually going on.However, recently I picked up the game again and started learning how to play it properly with the help of Scott Manley's YouTube video tutorials. Having spent the time learnuing how to orbit, redezvous and dock, it has opened up a tonne of depth to the game, allowing me to strike out to further places in the Kerbin system. Right now, I've now logged over 80 hours of play and I feel the game has so much more to offer and is being updated regularly by the authors. Opening up the game to mods was a great move and provides a wealth of tools and enhanced features.If you love space and can make your own fun in a sandbox environment, you're going to love this. I'm really looking forward to where this game will end up.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is excellent, though not for everyone. The game is challenging, and features realistic space flight and orbital mechanics. There is certainly a steep learning curve early on, but the difficulty makes the reward when you succeed that much greater. Beyond that, the game makes failure FUN! So don't think that you're going to get frustrated. If you have any interest in space flight, you will enjoy this game. The game will teach you about rocket science and the challenges of interplanetary travel.Build crazy rocket-powered contraptions, launch them into space, travel to moons and other planets throughout the system (an analog to the solar system). What's to dislike?Modes: there is currently a sandbox mode (all parts unlocked) and a Career mode (earn Science points by carrying out missions in order to unlock parts in the tech tree).The state of the game as it stands is very playable. There are some bugs, but it does not hinder the gameplay. The game is early access, so new content will be added in the future. Be warned: development is slow. However, SQUAD makes sure that each update is polished and robust before release, so the updates are worth the wait.Modability: there are TONS of mods for this game. Mods that add parts, mods that enhance the atmospherics, mods that turn the entire system in to the Solar System and scales it up to size, and more.TLDR: This game is loads of fun, even when your rockets are blowing up on the launchpad. Play sandbox and goof around with crazy contraptions, or play career for a fulfilling experience exploring, earning 'science' points and unlocking parts. Enjoy realistic orbital mechanics -- learn about real space flight!8.5/10

content:
Posted: April 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								I was gifted this game after raving about the demo to a friend (I think he gave it to me just to shut me up. Mission FAILED because I still haven't shut up about it.) I don't think I've been this excited about a game since the first Bioshock. It's incredibly entertaining as well as educational... I thought I had a good grasp of orbital mechanics until I tried to land on Mun. A lot of fun building rockets, launching and flying them, doing science (we do what we must, because we can), and the adorable 'minion'-like Kerbals are a draw. I *highly* recommend this game to anyone interested in space sciences or with kids who are.The game is still in active development and is not yet 'finished'.A couple nitpicks: 1) the career mode is too hard in that there are some basic funtionalities that are way up the tree (ladders??) and require a great deal of science points to unlock. There's definitely a sharp learning curve with, due to component unaavailability, a pronounced 'hump'. 2) There are no lady Kerbalnauts. This should be addressed for girl gamers' sake. Anyway, back to being obsessed with KSP. Just managed to land on Mun and get back so working on a Minmus landing mission. :-)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
Early Access Review
								9/10This game is still in early development alpha stage and yet I have played it more than any other Steam game. Don't let my "low" play time fool you, I must have over 200 extra hours I played before this was released on Steam.Despite being an alpha, Kerbal Space Program excels well. I honestly could believe this is a released game if it wasn't for the patchnotes and version number!The game itself alone can be played in sandbox or career mode. This means you can either start out with everything and just build wacky creations (incredible fun) or gradually build up the R&D to develop the different parts (gives way more pride). The feeling you get from completing the technology tree in career mode is incredible. Planning, building and flying missions makes me feel like a true rocket scientist.But surely that means you need to know rocket science? Well, not really. I started this game without any real knowledge of how spacecrafts get to orbit, how missions are structured or how different engines vary. I started originally by doing silly beginner mistakes, and slowly realised I could do things more efficiently a different way. I taught myself a lot about how orbital mechanics work, and the game inspired me to research more. I would say it's one of the biggest things that has driven my passion for space along with seeing Saturn through a telecope and watching a rocket launch from Kennedy Space Centre. So is the game centred around physics and orbital mechanics (bleh!)? Nope! While Kerbal Space Program brings many real life effects into account, and does its best to correctly model the physics acting upon bodies, you don't need to really pay much attention to this. For instance, you could build a huge plane and fly to the North Pole, or create a tank and drive around firing at buildings. This game can be as in depth as you'd like it to be.But what if science is your thing? Well then you're in luck because Kerbal Space Program allows you to whip out the calculator and start crunching those formulas. Several times I have been to wiki to remember the forumla for Delta V or when to make the most efficient transfer burn to one of the several other planets/moons. Mass, thrust, Isp, velocity and fuel quantities are all given to you by the game allowing you to plug them in to whatever equation you want allowing you to create several page booklets on each mission! I like to keep a notepad and pen closeby to scribble down some quick maths to make sure my missions will go off without a hitch.Not enough? Both the Forum and Space Port have hundreds of user-created (along with a few by users that have since been hired to work on the game itself) mods to install (via drag and drop, no hard installations!) and further expand the quantity and depth of your missions. Currently my favourite mod I am using makes unmanned vehicles need to be connected to Mission Control to be able to move, throttle, operate hardware and send back infomation. This means I have had to set up a telecommunications satellite array consisting of 4 ground stations, 6 geostationary satellites and 3 satellites orbiting each of the planet Kerbin's (your starting planet, similar to Earth) moons. Setting these up required some serious hard work and crazy amounts of logical thinking I didn't think I was capable of, but with it currently running perfectly I'm over the moon! (Ba dum tss)Remember; this game is still in Alpha: There are bugs, there are crashes, not everything you'd expect to be in the game is here yet. However, and more specifically recently, I have been seeing a huge drop in bugs. The physics engine could do with some work and aerodynamics leaves much to be desired. However, until this is further looked into by the devs, a marvelous user by the name of Ferram has created a mod to more accurately model aerodynamics. That's the way at the moment with KSP; Much like smartphones and apps, there's a mod for anything you'd want to do from going boating to recreating the Mir Space Station.I would highly recommend this game even if you aren't a huge fan of science or space because of the wacky, original fun you can have from messing around with this marvelous, beautiful game.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								I was gifted this game after raving about the demo to a friend (I think he gave it to me just to shut me up. Mission FAILED because I still haven't shut up about it.) I don't think I've been this excited about a game since the first Bioshock. It's incredibly entertaining as well as educational... I thought I had a good grasp of orbital mechanics until I tried to land on Mun. A lot of fun building rockets, launching and flying them, doing science (we do what we must, because we can), and the adorable 'minion'-like Kerbals are a draw. I *highly* recommend this game to anyone interested in space sciences or with kids who are.The game is still in active development and is not yet 'finished'.A couple nitpicks: 1) the career mode is too hard in that there are some basic funtionalities that are way up the tree (ladders??) and require a great deal of science points to unlock. There's definitely a sharp learning curve with, due to component unaavailability, a pronounced 'hump'. 2) There are no lady Kerbalnauts. This should be addressed for girl gamers' sake. Anyway, back to being obsessed with KSP. Just managed to land on Mun and get back so working on a Minmus landing mission. :-)

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 17, 2014
Early Access Review
								I think at one point when we were young everybody wanted to be an astronaut. Everyone dreams of flyinjg into outer space, exploring the cosmos. Well, you can do just that in this game. If you can get your rocket off the ground in one piece, that is.This game is what I suspect would be reality if NASA just did not give a ♥♥♥♥. For example, one time, I built a large rocket with four extra fuel canisters and boosters connected to the main one, which held the main thruster. As I lifted off, God chose to remind me right then and there that I forget to put on stage seperations parts, and promptly punished me for it. My craft was wieghed down, and after reach a couple hundred kilometers in the air it slowly descended to the dirt of Kerbal. Like the reincarnation of the Challenger Incident, the minor propulsion systems exploded first, leaving the main thruster to break apart limply on the ground before it too was engulfed in an explosion. This sent my cockpit, which carried three brave Kerbels(rest their souls) bouncing and skipping along the ground for a few seconds until they, too, exploded.tl;dr  Astronaut death simulator, 10/10 would play again.

								This game has the biggest learning curve I have ever encountered in a game. Hours upon hours have been wasted trying to build the perfect rocket, and time after time they fail. However, once you finally land on the Mun without any help, and completely on your own for the first time... that's one of the greatest feelings of accomplishment you will ever get out of a game. This might be my favorite game in my entire library.

content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game has changed me from a solid console gamer into a PC gamer. I have spend 300+ hours thus far in the game and it has been frustrating, rewarding and educational all at the same time. Launching a probe to the Gas Giant Jool and regreting not putting more science modules on board later when you have better building practices. So you do it all over agian. With the easy ability to mod, and the abundance of mods out for the game you are creating your own game, and it is a blast doing it!

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 27, 2014
Early Access Review
								Kerbal Space Program is the epitome of learning to fall with style. It is continuously amazing, continuously drawing my creative side, and it is continuously driving me to create bigger, better, and more likely to fail monsters of Aerospace. Career mode? That's a win but sandbox, the sandbox is where my own bread and butter is. It never gets old to push the limits of things and see how perfectly you can get something to fail. Yes, you will have a lot of failures but it contain the funnest amount of failing you've ever experienced. On top of that there is no greater pride than successfully launching something and taking it around the planet, to the Mun, and beyond. Fly forth little Kerbalnauts and here, you better read this apology for my ineptitude before you launch.

								KSP is one of the most fun educational games out there. After a few days playing this you'll sound like an astro-physist because you'll actually be reading books by astro-physists.

content:
Posted: April 29, 2013
Early Access Review
								I RECOMMEND THIS GAME!!!!Anything I say here probably wont do this game even a fathom of the recommendation this game deserves, I wouldnt even know where to begin to accurately describe this game; pictures give this game No justice, Not even Videos can, the KSP Demo itself gives the game barely a grain of sand worth of evidence as to how fun, cool, intense, nerve racking, Hard as Hell, Pleasing when you succeed, utterly shattered when you fail... And this still doesnt even begin the mile+ long list required to accurately portray all the aspects of this game.But, if you like building anything you can possibly think of so long as it has wheels, wings, or whatever you want... and dont mind risking it explode into a thousand pieces if you fail, or soaring through the empty limitless void of space should you succeed, mind you you might want to visit one of the ever growing list of universal objects you "can" visit, and by "can" i mean that if you can survive the harshness of space, the long distance trip(s), and not crash if you even get anywhere close to landing, then yes you can visit.Anyways, in short... Buy This Game. Its only gonna get better, and more expensive.
